content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Now, I've played a lot of MMO's over the past 8 years or so, mostly fantasy RPGs. Within the past 2 it has been surprisingly hard to find a solid contender for the "Action RPG", as I thought they would become more popular. I've been seeing nothing but, attempt, after attempt, of companies trying to produce an action oriented combat system, all but a select few falling very short of what I would consider polished, and functional. I played in the original release of Vindictus up until Evie was released, and picked it back up shortly after Kai was released.  The beginning was rough, with few characters, and the mission limits, with a token system that forced players to pay actual money to play more than a couple missions a day. However, now that stuff is gone, and what I see, and experience is a truly thought out, polished, and challenging combat system, that cannot be found in any other MMO out there. It is on par, and in some cases better than single player, full price fantasy RPGs. However, there are still major draw backs that prevent me from recommending it to everyone.  One; the way the game is set up, it forces players to go through one of the longest, and cruelest, grinds of any game I've ever played. By having all of the cool, and unique adventures restricted now, but not last March, to being level 50 or over. Many new players go in to try out this cool game, but are forced to drag themselves through repetitive areas, and a story that no-one is going to read,(Trust me, I tried), just to get to maps that are unique, and drastically more polished parts of the game. It's like giving someone a game, and saying, "These first 50 levels are just a test, to see if you're worthy of the good stuff". On a positive note, those forced 50 levels are fantastic practice, so you aren't likely to be terrible on your first major raid. I just don't understand the decision to increase the level restriction for the big raids in Malina.  Two; even though it has been said numerous times, the utter lack of choice a player has when making a character without paying a little for a hair style, or inner. It's brilliant business wise, I understand, but character customization is  huge factor to an increasingly large amount of MMO players. The simple lack of variety in new characters is a huge turn off, and a reason I can't give this game a perfect pass. Now, I've spent well over a few hundred dollars on this game, simply because I love it, and I'm invested into the characters I've spent over 500 hours with. When it comes down to it, there is a large audience that will give this game a shot and dwindle away shortly after reaching level 20 or so, since there isn't much to do, very few will continue on to actually play the "game".  In the end, Vindictus is a game that gives players an unparalleled action RPG experience, it may take a long time to dive into, but once you've past your "test", you'll likely never find another FREE* MMO that gives you a truly ambitious, and thrilling combat experience.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2012
												It's technically an MMO, but it plays like a multiplayer action game.This interesting hybrid of gameplay styles works wonderfully.In addition, Vindictus is compatible with xbox 360 controllers, and works quite well with them during dungeons. You'll still want a keyboard and mouse handy for the town areas and for typing and UI selections though.I find it difficult to enjoy most MMO titles, but this one really feels like you're playing an action title. The gameplay is fast paced and action oriented. Dungeons are initially doable solo, but eventually the difficulty ramps up too high for that.Thankfully, joining random groups is simple and streamlined. Quest and mission objectives are usually very straightforward and areas are fairly linear for the most part, so teaming up and working together with other players is rarely a chore or hassle.The story is a bit on the weak side, but the gameplay is the star of the show, and it shines brightly.

One of the things this game has going for it is the blatant and shameless sexuality that it promotes. That's one reason it does semi-well, due to the inner armors (underwear) that you can purshase for your character. Basically, what I'm trying to say is: "Just don't waste your time on this game." If you decide to play it, then just don't expect much. This game is designed to take a very long time to obtain items, whether they be weapons or armor, and it's also designed to nearly force you to spend money on it in order to protect your gear from potential failed enhancements or enchants, both of which can destroy your items. Anyway, I'll end this review.  That's it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Definitely a reccomendation for anyone who likes an MMORPG, but to prove it to you, let's give you a list of pros and cons- at least in my opinion of what are pros and cons. Pros: -The action is both fast paced and slow depending on which you prefer.-The actions in the trailer, the fighting? Exactly how you fight in game, but not as cool as in game. Odd, right? -The weapons are amazing looking as well as pets and everything else you obtain.-Wicked cool story line that has emotion, but also envokes you to play more- because you can't move forward until you beat missions. But that's not even a con, it's like watching a movie, gotta watch earlier parts to get the ending. -Lets you choose your own path for the story. Which way you lean, and how you want to fight yourself. -Amazing graphics.-Allows you to do raids, and work with a team for missions- Very helpful. -Did I mention the action was flippin' AMAZING? -If you say "Eh, I don't wanna play for a while." when you get pack, they give you stuff to say "PLS PLAY AGAIN" permanent epic weapons that aren't really rare, but sure look cool and are probably a step up from your old weapons, however it takes I believe 3 months of vacay from the game to get it. Now to the CONS: -Some stuff you have to pay for, but that's not too big a deal.-There are gaps in levels, where you have to grind to a certain level to move forward. -At times, it's very hard to play, sometimes the story won't finish until you repeat certain missions to even unlock the next place. -Limited weapons for your "class", don't get me wrong, it's nice to have weapons only your class can wield, but.. there's just not much variety, you get probably 3 weapons to choose from every 10-20 levels and at times it makes the choosing of appearance and how you wish to look for parties and what not rather dull. If they had more styles of weapons for your class, different shapes for them, more in general, it would improve the "fun-ness" of the game and make people more easily willing to play with more given choices. It's an amazing game, definitely worth playing. I have 275 hours logged into it and more are sure to come, but unless you want to play the game for a long time, and get involved with its story- it might not be for you. Keep that in mind. Other than that, a really enjoyable game, and free to play? Well, damn, sign me up! Oh wait, I already am.See you in Vindictus my friends! Battle on.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
												Ever wanted to be truly rewarded for your skill in a game? How about some action, RPG, and a whole lotta hack'n'slash? Vindictus is that game. Taking place thousands of years before the fantasy life MMORPG, Mabinogi, another Nexon title -- this game is definitely not about picking wool off a sheep or raising crops on a field. This is the most simple yet highly complex Action MMORPG out right now.Many have tried to emulate this style of MMO but Vindictus had laid forth a tyrant of an action game. Running on Valve's Source engine, the detail level of this game is simply gorgeous, the physics are top-notch (hilarious rag doll physics included), and monster AI will prove to give you a run for your golds at higher difficulties. Vindictus is mainly a dungeon crawling Action MMORPG with hub to dungeon travel via Story /Quest Boards and some stages may look repetitive and they are but as you keep playing, you'll find many other things to do. Welcome to the Vindictus where skill matters..

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I really and truly want to give this game a positive review, but I simply cannot bring myself to.To start, Vindictus is an MMORPG and Hack n' Slash game that really misses the MMO portion of its genre. It has features of one, like a global marketplace and raids and the sort, but it stops there. There are only two cities in the entire game and a field that seperates them with little activity in either one. Aside from queing for battles, there isn't much to do in the locations, there's crafting and quest givers that can provide some interesting dialouge, but it stops there. Honestly, this isn't too much of a problem compared to the more pressing problems I have with the game.Gameplay is very solid, however, the skill tree for each of the playable characters is very diverese as each character is allowed to use two different weapons in their class; such as a mage who can choose to use a scythe or a staff or a tank that can use either a pillar or cestus as a weapon. Each provide their own strengths and weaknesses in their own regard and I found it enjoyable learning the combos and intricacies of each weapon and skill. Unfortunately, the pros for the game stop at the gameplay. The largest problem I have with the game is the developer; for those that don't know, Nexon is a very greedy company. The in-game store offers a range of items that either change the cosmetic appearance or provide a game breaking and pay-to-win experiance like buying items that buff your stats to paying to allow yourself to do more raids, it's downright criminal. The downfall of this also comes into the heafty price they ask for literally EVERYTHING. Just to change the hairstyle of your character (as you can only choose about 5 when you first start, then have to pay, seperately, for the additional 20 Nexon expects you to buy) runs you about $7. Want to change your clothes? $10. Want to be able to do more daily raids? $10. Another serious problem with Nexon is their support for the game. While the branches of Nexon in various other areas of the world like in Europe or Asia recieve timely patches to the game that actually provide new content like new characters, new locations, new raids, etc. The Nexon supporting this version, Nexon NA, is the about the most incompetent company I have seen. Instead of working on updates that the community has been begging for, they keep making new events that act as little mini-games or side missions you can do that, SURPRISE, you have to pay real money in order to even finish, and sometimes even participate in.Probably the largest problem I have with the game, despite how dreadful the company is, is the absoltuely absurd grind that you have to do at high levels. The main story lasts from levels 1-60, which is not that bad and you may end up being overleveled for some missions you must do, but after you finish the main story comes the real pain. From 60, the level cap is 80, and you can obtain the best weapons and armor in the game, but in order to do this requires you to not only grind many, many hours away hoping you get the materials required to make a weapon or piece of armor, but to withstand the god awful drop rate that about every item has. The drop table is about as bad as the enhancing and upgrading system in the game. To make matters worse, in order to even get the item you need, you have to grind raids. Remember what I said about how greedy Nexon was? Well you can only run the raids you need about 3 times or so a day, so if you really want those materials, you better pull out your wallet because grinding that raid is gonna cost you extra.Honestly, I really want to recommend this game to everyone, but unless this game gets taken over by a more respectable and competent company, I simply can't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												*sighs*as of 6-17-2014 I can no longer recoemend Vindictus.Nexon's greed and Devcats incompentence is slowly but steadly driving the game into the dirt.Firstly, there is the removeal of the jumping mechanic. Granted it was poorly implemented to begin with, but instead of opting to fix it, the instead removed it, and sunsquently reworked all of seaon 2, map lay out and enemys, to compenstate for the player no longer being able to jump.Secondly, they actually removed the option to run season 2 from levels 8-49. Because high level players where farming them for Seals (needed to buy high end mats) and AP (needed to rank up skills, some of which need 2 or 3k per rank and you at best, getting 250) so again, instead of fixing the issue, they just removed a chunk of the game. Then there what Nexon it self is doing, since Devcat isn't the only one ruining this thing.The cash shop is starting to lean toward a 'pay2win' model, granted, it's still a LONG way from that, but it's starting down that road, from the overpriced pets who grant extra, and rather potentant effects like buffs or mining ore for you, to the laughably over priced Enchantment, and Enhancement Runes that are pretty much required to be usefull in the 70-80 tier content, The 'events' are pretty much ONLY for lining Nexon pockets with money, with what ever free items being little more then the cheapest items in the cash shop, while what ever good items that are attatched are only attainable vai 'random item' boxes you buy from the cash shop, with a rather horrible chance of actually getting the event item, as you'd probably expect.Speaking of the RNG, It's horrible here. Drop rates have always been bad in this game, but pretty much any equipment worth using level 60 and up requires AT LEAST one ultra rare mateiral drop, per piece, and I don't mean 'I've been farming for a week and finally got one' rare, I mean 'this raid has been out for a year, I've been running it daily, still haven't gotten the drop I need' rare. Sadly, I'm not exagerating ether. The RNG ties into the final issue I want to mention. the price of things. The amount of gold you need to cercumvent the drop rates is prohibitive to every one who isn't willing to risk getting ripped off to buy gold. the Seal Shop, which sells the ultra rare mateirs you need, is suppossed to combat the drop rate issue, but it really just added to the grind problem, with some taking anywhere from 5 days, to more then a month of JUST Seal farming to get. (12 seals per day, 1 seal per raid run, 1 victory per raid a day)The actual gameplay it self is still fun, but Nexon effectively destoryed what ever potental it had utterly through greed and imcompatence. The game is dieing, and at this point, I say let it.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I've been playing it since the open beta 2 years agoVindictus is an action based MMO the centers on instances, and TRUE SKILL when fighting bosses. to win you need to learn a bosses tells and openings, you gear, even maxed out, only makes up about 10%, at best, of your odds of winning, the rest is on you, the player.armor and weapons must be made by gathering matierals from bosses anf raid bosses, with the only short cut being the auction house, and even then all gear has a level and skill requirement, even the stuff in the cash shops weapon/armor packs, which are filled with imporved gear, you can make on your own with out spending a dime.the cash shop it self is mostly about convienace, potions, graces and invintory space will likely be the bulk of your purchices, along with some avatar items to make you character look better.all in all, it is a good game that deserves more attention then its gotten, and despite what Tera says, Vindictus IS the first true action MMO

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												First of all, i come from the beta days. Back when there was only 3 characters and Evie still swung around her staff as a melee weapon (which is funny cause her doppelganger in the labyrinth still does this).  There are now 9 characters, each with very different styles of play, VERY pretty and powerful skills and while it can get a tad repetitive it's still enjoyable. While i do not support Nexon, i support this game. It's pay2lookgood, not pay2win. You can do everything you need to without paying a cent which is what free2play games are supposed to be. Granted progress may be slower than what you "could" be getting but that's just how F2P games stay afloat. They take advantage of impatience and what people want which depending on your stance may be a good or bad thing. Regardless, if people didn't want to throw money at these things, they wouldn't exist. Fact of the matter is, people want to play games but they don't want to spend money on them, which is another reason why F2P games are so popular.Now for the meat.The game itself is entertaining, dialog is nice and funny if a little dodgy in the translations every once in a while. The season 1 story gets interesting at around level 30-40ish and i found myself losing even more hours to it as i went back to discover more and i haven't played much of the second season yet.You level fairly quickly in the beginning and I only really noticed a big slow down at around 40-50. Which isn't bad considering you get most of your characters main skills at around 30, so you have a good idea of their capabilities and play style. The combat itself is similar to a Dynasty Warriors game, which you use heavy movement and large attacks to damage enemies that come at you in small groups of up to i think 10 at once in some areas.Missions consist of an instance for your party, which for normal missions is a max of 4 people. Later on, you find larger raid boss missions that can have anywhere from 6 people all the way to 20+ The big boss battles are fun and are easy once you know what their attacks are and how they will react to yours. I am also under the assumption that every mission in the game is solo-able if you are just that good, i however am not. I can play just about everything in season 1 by myself but need a decent party for the big raid bosses.The community from what i've seen isn't as trolly and elietest as some might say, whether they used to be or not i have no idea but i've not come across very many distasteful people in the times i've played. I also play on the West server, due to my understanding of it being strictly the U.S server, while the East server is Europe's. I have at least 100 hours if not a bit more, as i don't play as often as i used to but i have two characters 60+ and others in their 40's-50's. The anime-esc visuals are quite pretty and the game can get quite fan-servicey which is also a love or hate type of deal. I personally love being able to look good and even some of the full armor sets look very good on either gender. Character creation is somewhat limited as you pick a pre-determined character but get to mess around with them a bit. Changing hair, height, size of various body aspects, tattoos and skin color, as well as their underwear which "can" consist of skimpy outfits but there are non skimpy options as well.Lastly, i am not an MMO person. I don't typically like the styles they use and i don't really play the ones i like most of the time. But Vindictus is one of those games i enjoy and still come back to and it's loads better when you play and level with friends. I don't think it's the best game out there cause it's sure as hell not but it's free so it's something you don't have to devote time and money to if you don't want to. That being said, some of the money options are very helpful, and a couple of them are rather dumb but it doesn't hurt the experience much at all. It's free, you don't need to spend any money to do what everyone else can do. Just play it for a while, get to around level 20 and then decide if it's worth your time or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
												Ever wanted to be truly rewarded for your skill in a game? How about some action, RPG, and a whole lotta hack'n'slash? Vindictus is that game. Taking place thousands of years before the fantasy life MMORPG, Mabinogi, another Nexon title -- this game is definitely not about picking wool off a sheep or raising crops on a field. This is the most simple yet highly complex Action MMORPG out right now.Many have tried to emulate this style of MMO but Vindictus had laid forth a tyrant of an action game. Running on Valve's Source engine, the detail level of this game is simply gorgeous, the physics are top-notch (hilarious rag doll physics included), and monster AI will prove to give you a run for your golds at higher difficulties. Vindictus is mainly a dungeon crawling Action MMORPG with hub to dungeon travel via Story /Quest Boards and some stages may look repetitive and they are but as you keep playing, you'll find many other things to do. Welcome to the Vindictus where skill matters..

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Definitely a reccomendation for anyone who likes an MMORPG, but to prove it to you, let's give you a list of pros and cons- at least in my opinion of what are pros and cons. Pros: -The action is both fast paced and slow depending on which you prefer.-The actions in the trailer, the fighting? Exactly how you fight in game, but not as cool as in game. Odd, right? -The weapons are amazing looking as well as pets and everything else you obtain.-Wicked cool story line that has emotion, but also envokes you to play more- because you can't move forward until you beat missions. But that's not even a con, it's like watching a movie, gotta watch earlier parts to get the ending. -Lets you choose your own path for the story. Which way you lean, and how you want to fight yourself. -Amazing graphics.-Allows you to do raids, and work with a team for missions- Very helpful. -Did I mention the action was flippin' AMAZING? -If you say "Eh, I don't wanna play for a while." when you get pack, they give you stuff to say "PLS PLAY AGAIN" permanent epic weapons that aren't really rare, but sure look cool and are probably a step up from your old weapons, however it takes I believe 3 months of vacay from the game to get it. Now to the CONS: -Some stuff you have to pay for, but that's not too big a deal.-There are gaps in levels, where you have to grind to a certain level to move forward. -At times, it's very hard to play, sometimes the story won't finish until you repeat certain missions to even unlock the next place. -Limited weapons for your "class", don't get me wrong, it's nice to have weapons only your class can wield, but.. there's just not much variety, you get probably 3 weapons to choose from every 10-20 levels and at times it makes the choosing of appearance and how you wish to look for parties and what not rather dull. If they had more styles of weapons for your class, different shapes for them, more in general, it would improve the "fun-ness" of the game and make people more easily willing to play with more given choices. It's an amazing game, definitely worth playing. I have 275 hours logged into it and more are sure to come, but unless you want to play the game for a long time, and get involved with its story- it might not be for you. Keep that in mind. Other than that, a really enjoyable game, and free to play? Well, damn, sign me up! Oh wait, I already am.See you in Vindictus my friends! Battle on.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												A great rpg game. While it is not what I originally expected (openworld mmorpg), I thoroughly enjoy this game. It is by no means, Pay 2 Win in which the only way to get to endgame is by paying for weapons and xp boosts. I am a playing this game spending no money what so ever. The wonderful thing about this game is the marketplace which makes playing for free possible. By going into the levels or battle quests, you can aquire goods and materials which you can sell on the market. I was able to make a million gold (ingame currency) by just doing quests, some grinding, and aquiring uncommon and rare materials which I won't use and selling them. It's a great process which might get old if you get bored easily. I do not so it's fine. You pay in this game for xp boosts which is a given as well as cosmetic options which are totally up to you.The second thing I enjoy about this game is the diversity of armor and gear to wear and use. A long time mmorpg gamer, I cringed constantly of the "battle armor" my female characters were subjected  to. Why couldn't I have a badass, fully armored female knight or soldier? Here in Vindictus, you can. The armors are practical and look good in my view. Of course there are some sexy and fetish-like outfits for both genders but for the most part they are tamed by most standards, *cough cough* TERA. Anyway, I highly recommend this game since you won't lose a thing, this game is free 2 play in the most beautiful sense and a worth a look.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Edit: I have tried to include all of the different aspects of the game in here, so if there is something that you look for specifically in a game, then you can look through the categories to find what stands out to you.If you like to play games for just the mechanics and gameplay itself, then this is the game for you, as it doesn't really attempt to do anything other than master those two aspects. I think that the best way to review this game is to review everything individually, as because it's so focused around one aspect you can see the short-comings of the game more clearly... so here goes.Combat/Fighting/Action_Score - 9.5/10 I rate this a almost perfect score because I believe that Vindictus still has the best combat system of any action MMO that I have ever played. It is quick, deadly and punishing, and reminds me alot of Dark Souls with a bit more flashiness and speed. Where the combat is flawed is tied into the gameplay, as it eventually becomes less enjoyable when you have to participate in an extreme amount of grinding 70+; however, the repetitiveness I will review in more depth below.Mechanics/Movement/Dodging_Score - 9/10 I feel like this piece of the game needs a separate review from the combat, because it is about the controls and flow more than the actual combat itself. This game is designed extremely well to fit a player's skill level, and isn't a game that relies on equipment (even though it's a very apparent factor when doing raids later on). It doesn't take a long time to get good at dodging and movement as you fight multiple hard-hitting bosses that you are pretty much required to dodge. The only downside of the mechanics is that no matter how good you've become you will need to reach certain gear requirements late game regardless of your skill level, as many of the raids late game require you to have a certain ATTK requirement. This became quite frustrating for me when I had to grind for hours to get enough gold for new equipment, only to join the raids, upon which I witness players who didn't seem like they had really grasped the dodging mechanic.Graphics/Optimization/Requirements_Score - 8/10 This is another strong area for the game, as the game is optimized very well to allow people to play even on low-end computers with smooth fps. The graphics themselves are good too, and it doesn't take a beefy graphics card too make it look pretty sexy. To go a little deeper I would say that I thought that the textures were really good on max settings, and the meshes for different objects were decent too. I gave this category an 8/10 simply because the graphics are good, but nowhere near perfect.Characters/Appearance/Custimization_Score - 7/10 The characters on this game are very beautifully made and are extremely good looking ( males and females -.O). There are two reasons why I rated this category as low as I did. The first - most major reason - is that the characters/classes are all gender locked, so right off the bat you will not be able to pick which gender you are if you like to play a certain style of class, and even though this doesn't really bother me too much, alot of people feel like this is a critical part of customization. The other - more minor reason - is that to really customize your character, you will have to spend NX. This is minor because it's pretty much the main purpose of NX aside from bonuses, making this game - for the most part - not Pay2Win, although it does suck that if you do not spend money they hook you up with this silly♥♥♥♥♥inner armor (underwear) that ruins the look of a majority of armors in the game. A way that I'm guessing they wanted to counter this fault is by creating the AP Shop, where you can buy inner amor and hair coupons that last 30 days; however, they cost over 1k AP , which is too much for someone who hasn't already maxed their skills to pay for a 30 day coupon.Cash Shop/NX/Avatar Shop_Score - 6/10 As you may have noticed the categories are in a descending order, and I will continue like this until I get to the worst parts of the game. The cash shop on Vindictus (The Supply Depot) is slightly better than I see in most games. As I said before, this game isn't really Pay2Win, and this is the case because the things you buy in the Supply Depot are really nice bonuses to have, but the flow of the game is not affected or hindered if you choose not to purchase anything from the Supply Depot. The other shop that they have is the Avatar Shop, and it is a bit more dissapointing then the more basic Supply Depot. This is also because of how NX works in this game. There is prepaid NX, which you get from cards that you buy at the store (also the best to have), and then there is NX credit, which is a purchase that you make online with a credit card. There are certain thing in the Avatar Shop you can only buy with NX prepaid, as there are no restrictions on the prepaid NX that you buy from the store, and there is on NX credit.Mercenaries/NPCs/Story_Score - 4/10 The story in this game - in short - is a snooze. I think that if you're looking for a game with a really good story then you should perhaps look elsewhere, as this game will not sastify you. For me I honestly really enjoyed the stories of the mercenaries you get when you pick your first character more than I enjoyed the different seasons' stories. I would have loved to see the stories of the mercenaries continued throughout the main quest; however, the main fault is that the game is just too focused on it's action to worry about anything else. The action is the very base of this game, and if you like action then this is a good game for you, but what the devs did was take the action of the game, and then they slapped all of this mediocre content around that base so that they could make it a better game. While this is respectable, they clearly rushed the story to fit the fast pace gameplay, which really didn't work. I read through all of the dialouge in the first chapter and then I just starting clicking through it because I had lost interest.Community/Players/Guilds_Score - 4/10 To test the community I made several different characters and joined in some basic guilds by simply asking in chat. I'm not going to name any guilds in particular because I wouldn't want to hurt their rep, but there was only 2 guilds I found where the players weren't rude. This is of course all based off of my experience so it is a very rough estimate, and because of this I'm gonna say there is maybe a 50/50 chance you end up in a good guild when you start off. The best thing to do is to find a guild that you like that will accept alts, and stick with them on your multitude of characters. Finding that guild... that may prove challenging.Now for the worst...Grinding/Mobs/Repetitiveness_Score - 2/10 This is for me the worst part of the game. If there is even a small part of you that doesn't enjoy repetitiveness, you may want to consider something else. The only thing that makes this flaw of the game less severe is that it really isn't the biggest part of the game. Get rid of the Dark Souls-esque combat and you have a game that has generic mobs that you will need to grind for hours for better equipment, in order to meet ATTK requirements. I also noticed that later on in the game, even when mobs look slightly different, they still look almost exactly the same. For those of you that have already played Vindictus, the reason why this is so low is because I don't include bosses in this category, because I feel like bosses needed to be separated from mobs because of the quality difference. Bosses are part of my review of the gameplay and mechanics because of the fact that they are part of what makes this game great, and they deserve to be separated from the mobs. If at first you don't think something like the mobs or Batte Quests are repetitive, wait til you must grind them for hours on end.Overall Score - 6.2/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game becomes pay-to-win after level 50 or 60. There aren't enough people playing to put together a party of 2 let alone a party of 6 to 8 required for many of the raid bosses (which are required to beat in order to progress). This pushes players to go solo* which isn't realistically possible unless you spend real money on Goddess Graces (revive your self when you die) and Merc healing pots. I didn't mind spending money on things like inner armor (under wear), more storage, extra character slots etc. But I refuse to pay to progress.The developers have come up with some of the laziest boss designs I've seen in a while. Far too many bosses in this game have adds. Remember how cheap Capra Demon felt in Dark Souls - not really challenging once the dogs were gone? This developer decided to take that cheapness to a whole new level with dozens of bosses that have a dozen adds or more, some of them continually respawn through out the boss fights. The developer also decided to toss in a few bosses (like Thor) that can one shot kill any character. Lazy!The servers are ridiculously slow, and the game is buggy. Wait an hour to get a small team together for a raid just to have the server eject everyone from the party and toss all the characters back in town.It's a shame because the first 3 or 4 locations in the game are pretty good. They're realistically solo-able, even on harder difficulty settings, if you learn the boss move sets and timing. There are enough new people playing these early levels (that haven't quit yet) that getting a team together for a raid doesn't take an eternity.  Then the game turns to crap around Hoarfrost Depths so most new players just quit, leaving anyone with a desire to continue faced with waiting hours or paying to solo.*The developer is falsely claiming that this game is single-player on the Steam store page.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I really and truly want to give this game a positive review, but I simply cannot bring myself to.To start, Vindictus is an MMORPG and Hack n' Slash game that really misses the MMO portion of its genre. It has features of one, like a global marketplace and raids and the sort, but it stops there. There are only two cities in the entire game and a field that seperates them with little activity in either one. Aside from queing for battles, there isn't much to do in the locations, there's crafting and quest givers that can provide some interesting dialouge, but it stops there. Honestly, this isn't too much of a problem compared to the more pressing problems I have with the game.Gameplay is very solid, however, the skill tree for each of the playable characters is very diverese as each character is allowed to use two different weapons in their class; such as a mage who can choose to use a scythe or a staff or a tank that can use either a pillar or cestus as a weapon. Each provide their own strengths and weaknesses in their own regard and I found it enjoyable learning the combos and intricacies of each weapon and skill. Unfortunately, the pros for the game stop at the gameplay. The largest problem I have with the game is the developer; for those that don't know, Nexon is a very greedy company. The in-game store offers a range of items that either change the cosmetic appearance or provide a game breaking and pay-to-win experiance like buying items that buff your stats to paying to allow yourself to do more raids, it's downright criminal. The downfall of this also comes into the heafty price they ask for literally EVERYTHING. Just to change the hairstyle of your character (as you can only choose about 5 when you first start, then have to pay, seperately, for the additional 20 Nexon expects you to buy) runs you about $7. Want to change your clothes? $10. Want to be able to do more daily raids? $10. Another serious problem with Nexon is their support for the game. While the branches of Nexon in various other areas of the world like in Europe or Asia recieve timely patches to the game that actually provide new content like new characters, new locations, new raids, etc. The Nexon supporting this version, Nexon NA, is the about the most incompetent company I have seen. Instead of working on updates that the community has been begging for, they keep making new events that act as little mini-games or side missions you can do that, SURPRISE, you have to pay real money in order to even finish, and sometimes even participate in.Probably the largest problem I have with the game, despite how dreadful the company is, is the absoltuely absurd grind that you have to do at high levels. The main story lasts from levels 1-60, which is not that bad and you may end up being overleveled for some missions you must do, but after you finish the main story comes the real pain. From 60, the level cap is 80, and you can obtain the best weapons and armor in the game, but in order to do this requires you to not only grind many, many hours away hoping you get the materials required to make a weapon or piece of armor, but to withstand the god awful drop rate that about every item has. The drop table is about as bad as the enhancing and upgrading system in the game. To make matters worse, in order to even get the item you need, you have to grind raids. Remember what I said about how greedy Nexon was? Well you can only run the raids you need about 3 times or so a day, so if you really want those materials, you better pull out your wallet because grinding that raid is gonna cost you extra.Honestly, I really want to recommend this game to everyone, but unless this game gets taken over by a more respectable and competent company, I simply can't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												*sighs*as of 6-17-2014 I can no longer recoemend Vindictus.Nexon's greed and Devcats incompentence is slowly but steadly driving the game into the dirt.Firstly, there is the removeal of the jumping mechanic. Granted it was poorly implemented to begin with, but instead of opting to fix it, the instead removed it, and sunsquently reworked all of seaon 2, map lay out and enemys, to compenstate for the player no longer being able to jump.Secondly, they actually removed the option to run season 2 from levels 8-49. Because high level players where farming them for Seals (needed to buy high end mats) and AP (needed to rank up skills, some of which need 2 or 3k per rank and you at best, getting 250) so again, instead of fixing the issue, they just removed a chunk of the game. Then there what Nexon it self is doing, since Devcat isn't the only one ruining this thing.The cash shop is starting to lean toward a 'pay2win' model, granted, it's still a LONG way from that, but it's starting down that road, from the overpriced pets who grant extra, and rather potentant effects like buffs or mining ore for you, to the laughably over priced Enchantment, and Enhancement Runes that are pretty much required to be usefull in the 70-80 tier content, The 'events' are pretty much ONLY for lining Nexon pockets with money, with what ever free items being little more then the cheapest items in the cash shop, while what ever good items that are attatched are only attainable vai 'random item' boxes you buy from the cash shop, with a rather horrible chance of actually getting the event item, as you'd probably expect.Speaking of the RNG, It's horrible here. Drop rates have always been bad in this game, but pretty much any equipment worth using level 60 and up requires AT LEAST one ultra rare mateiral drop, per piece, and I don't mean 'I've been farming for a week and finally got one' rare, I mean 'this raid has been out for a year, I've been running it daily, still haven't gotten the drop I need' rare. Sadly, I'm not exagerating ether. The RNG ties into the final issue I want to mention. the price of things. The amount of gold you need to cercumvent the drop rates is prohibitive to every one who isn't willing to risk getting ripped off to buy gold. the Seal Shop, which sells the ultra rare mateirs you need, is suppossed to combat the drop rate issue, but it really just added to the grind problem, with some taking anywhere from 5 days, to more then a month of JUST Seal farming to get. (12 seals per day, 1 seal per raid run, 1 victory per raid a day)The actual gameplay it self is still fun, but Nexon effectively destoryed what ever potental it had utterly through greed and imcompatence. The game is dieing, and at this point, I say let it.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I've been playing it since the open beta 2 years agoVindictus is an action based MMO the centers on instances, and TRUE SKILL when fighting bosses. to win you need to learn a bosses tells and openings, you gear, even maxed out, only makes up about 10%, at best, of your odds of winning, the rest is on you, the player.armor and weapons must be made by gathering matierals from bosses anf raid bosses, with the only short cut being the auction house, and even then all gear has a level and skill requirement, even the stuff in the cash shops weapon/armor packs, which are filled with imporved gear, you can make on your own with out spending a dime.the cash shop it self is mostly about convienace, potions, graces and invintory space will likely be the bulk of your purchices, along with some avatar items to make you character look better.all in all, it is a good game that deserves more attention then its gotten, and despite what Tera says, Vindictus IS the first true action MMO

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												The only thing I have to say about this game: It's okay.Honestly, I'm not the most experienced person on the game, but I can see one thing that Nexon had brought back in yet another game; Pay2Win. There's level 85's tricked out with all their fancy clothes, and if you spend maybe 10 minutes on the game you can pretty much say that it's impossible to get even close to 85 without countless hours of grinding.. And grinding... and more grinding. Once you get past level 30, a good 45 minutes of grinding will get you maybe 2-3 levels at most. (60+ = 1 hour for a level. Roughly.) There's some good DPS classes, such as the twin swords or glaive, and there's a lot of other variety to choose from (such as a battle pillar or scythe/staff), and their damage really depends on the weapon, in my perspective. So, for appearance of the game. You'll start off with a fairly good selection of characters. You've got your classic shield and sword, some big tank guy with a hulky piece o' wood, twin swords, archer, etc. This is where the game can get decieving. You'll start out seeing these characters in pretty bada** clothing, girls lookin' finnnnneeee, but when you enter the game, guess what? You've got some boots, some pants, and a sweater with a hood. *Wonderful.* Get past the fact you won't get some good looking clothes until level 30-ish, and you're good. Right? No. Your weapon, let's use a spellsword for example, is made of wood and you won't get anything that'll get a second glance until level 50 or so(speaking from opinion and experience). This spellsword does a tidbit of damage, and unless you really want to start making some damage, you're going to need to resort to your mana and/or secondary weapon. On a different note, the graphics of the game are pretty good, considering it is an MMO. It ran smoothly on my craptop, which is a $300 piece of, well, crap. The first levels, or missions, get EXTREMELY repititive. You've got about 4 different rooms in the first area place thingy-magij, and they're just placed in a different order every time you play. Yeah, sure, it takes about 40 minutes of solid gameplay to get through everything, and that's not counting the leveling up you need to do between missions. Congratulations, you've got through the first area! Onto the next one. Hoarfrost Hollow? Icy, a little better in map interaction. Wait; Ainle is next. Hoarfrost.. (*insert snickering 12-year-olds-here*) Ok, seriously, the maps and graphics are great, considering what this game is. Overall 6/10. Not bad, but it could use work, and Nexon needs to stoP MAKING PAY2WIN. PLEASE, NEXON.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												It's really disapointing, honestly.  The story is nothing to write home about, some of the characters are interesting, the questing is rather dull (and heavily RNG'd on the Side Quests) but my biggest problem in this game comes from the insane difficulty spikes in higher level content.I'm fine with tough fights.  I love a challenging encounter.  A fight with a boss that can one shot anyone, hit half the arena (and not even as a special attack, that's just one of many) with no possible angle of attack where you can't get annihilated by a random attack with a 0.5 second tell.  God help you if you ever lag.You can suggest that I'm bad at games if you want, but the real reason for this is actually quite brilliant.  This Nexon game allows you to buy 'Extra Lives', so making the end game raid fights as punishing as possible is 'good' game design.I love this game's combat system.  It flows nicely, it's entertaining and the animation/sound effects really sells the strength of the hits.  It's only a shame that such a good game was given to Nexon to monitize.  This game system with a better publisher would have been amazing.As it stands, if you want to romp around and just kill some grunts with a good combat system, it's good for that.  It's almost got a Dynasty Warriors feel to it, depending on the character you pick.  However, when you get to the late game there won't be anything for you but brutally punishing 'Raid' battles that stand between you and continuing the story.  I don't mean one or two, by the way.  The last DOZEN quests of Season 1 contain at least 9 Raids.  Hope you have a lot of friends, or like waiting for people to join your party so you can keep playing the game.Fun for a quick romp, but look elsewhere if you want anything of substance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Pros: Plenty of character customization, combat is good and stylish, Character models and armor look goodCons: Environments are definitely second to the characters in detail, poor community, gets stale quickly, PvP is a joke, Feels very small in scale due to the fact that there is only lobbies and instances nothing else, story is entirely forgettable, lots of server issues, and P2WSo to explain a bit, I have put a fair amount of time into this game (1000+ hrs) so it is most definitely something i know what im talking about. It has good looking characters with plenty of customization and there really isnt another online game with combat like it, but thats the extent of its good. The game story is completely forgettable and you will be spending most of the time attempting to skip it when speaking with an NPC, voice acting for cut scenes is C grade at a stretch. The whole lobby/dungeon system and no open world really makes it feel confined and serves to simply diminish the feeling of there being any real content. Youll run the same runs with the same scenery over and over and over and over, itd be one thing if you could explorer a vast and beautiful world but you cant, it doesnt exist outside your small towns. Speaking of the environments they are rather poorly made, they get the job done but in contrast to the characters they look like crap until you get to certain parts of Season 2 but still very dull in appearance and not much life to them. Once you reach endgame its going to be a 6 month if youre lucky grind but more than likely years of grinding to get endgame gear due to extremely low drop rates which by the time you get it will be outdated anyway. You will be forced to spend money and find less than admirable ways to acquire the gear for you to be considered relevant (lots of P2W in Vindi). On that topic you will also find yourself in a community with a rather heavy elitist attitude to it, many are not newbie friendly and if you dont have endgame gear will get kicked frequently from boats later in the game which increases the difficulty of getting endgame gear even more. PvP is an absolute joke and was shackled on later in the games life and it shows as there is little reason to actually do it outside of it being forced in order to get certain items. This game has lots of potential, and the combat is great, but nexon has not done anything to really keep the player outside of plenty of TnA. The servers also have lots of issues and you will disconnect and lag ALOT. Once you reach that pinnacle of endgame gear and such there will be nothing left but to chat in lobby 1 and wait for the new raids with the "better" gear which wont come till they increase the level cap so there are large expanses with new content but only side grades of gear with different aesthetics.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												First of all, i come from the beta days. Back when there was only 3 characters and Evie still swung around her staff as a melee weapon (which is funny cause her doppelganger in the labyrinth still does this).  There are now 9 characters, each with very different styles of play, VERY pretty and powerful skills and while it can get a tad repetitive it's still enjoyable. While i do not support Nexon, i support this game. It's pay2lookgood, not pay2win. You can do everything you need to without paying a cent which is what free2play games are supposed to be. Granted progress may be slower than what you "could" be getting but that's just how F2P games stay afloat. They take advantage of impatience and what people want which depending on your stance may be a good or bad thing. Regardless, if people didn't want to throw money at these things, they wouldn't exist. Fact of the matter is, people want to play games but they don't want to spend money on them, which is another reason why F2P games are so popular.Now for the meat.The game itself is entertaining, dialog is nice and funny if a little dodgy in the translations every once in a while. The season 1 story gets interesting at around level 30-40ish and i found myself losing even more hours to it as i went back to discover more and i haven't played much of the second season yet.You level fairly quickly in the beginning and I only really noticed a big slow down at around 40-50. Which isn't bad considering you get most of your characters main skills at around 30, so you have a good idea of their capabilities and play style. The combat itself is similar to a Dynasty Warriors game, which you use heavy movement and large attacks to damage enemies that come at you in small groups of up to i think 10 at once in some areas.Missions consist of an instance for your party, which for normal missions is a max of 4 people. Later on, you find larger raid boss missions that can have anywhere from 6 people all the way to 20+ The big boss battles are fun and are easy once you know what their attacks are and how they will react to yours. I am also under the assumption that every mission in the game is solo-able if you are just that good, i however am not. I can play just about everything in season 1 by myself but need a decent party for the big raid bosses.The community from what i've seen isn't as trolly and elietest as some might say, whether they used to be or not i have no idea but i've not come across very many distasteful people in the times i've played. I also play on the West server, due to my understanding of it being strictly the U.S server, while the East server is Europe's. I have at least 100 hours if not a bit more, as i don't play as often as i used to but i have two characters 60+ and others in their 40's-50's. The anime-esc visuals are quite pretty and the game can get quite fan-servicey which is also a love or hate type of deal. I personally love being able to look good and even some of the full armor sets look very good on either gender. Character creation is somewhat limited as you pick a pre-determined character but get to mess around with them a bit. Changing hair, height, size of various body aspects, tattoos and skin color, as well as their underwear which "can" consist of skimpy outfits but there are non skimpy options as well.Lastly, i am not an MMO person. I don't typically like the styles they use and i don't really play the ones i like most of the time. But Vindictus is one of those games i enjoy and still come back to and it's loads better when you play and level with friends. I don't think it's the best game out there cause it's sure as hell not but it's free so it's something you don't have to devote time and money to if you don't want to. That being said, some of the money options are very helpful, and a couple of them are rather dumb but it doesn't hurt the experience much at all. It's free, you don't need to spend any money to do what everyone else can do. Just play it for a while, get to around level 20 and then decide if it's worth your time or not.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This is an MMO with most of the standard stuff... Cash shop (not pay2win), grind walls, lots of people, nice guys,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bags, and all of the rest in between. BUT this game comes with the BEST action combat I've ever played! There are games I've payed for that don't come close to this level of awesome. The graphics are actually really good for a game with Dx9 and built on the source engine. The bosses are creative and sometimes irritatingly difficult (but then you just bring a bud and wipe the floor with'em).PvP? Couldn't tell ya how it is because I don't like to fight people on games like this... so I don't and it doesn't hinder the gaming experience on bit.The music is good too and gets you pumped for fightsThen there are the wide variety of classes to choose from. At the moment there is a character for nearly every playstyle. The only one they don't have is one that uses stealth as their primary form of defence.The only down side I see to this game is the RNG is aweful and can ruin your character by destroying the only weapon you own and leaving you with no money left. You sometimes have to have extreme luck for that NOT to happen. Good thing about that is you only have to worry about it during the late end game stuff.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												I've been casually playing this game on and off for several years (since the removal of the limited boarding system), and I have to agree with most of the top reviews: Nexon is a pretty bad company. Joining Steam has opened up the game to a much bigger and diverse gaming community, and I definitely appreciate the presence of new Steam players hopping on. Here are some pros & cons.Pros:+ Excellent artistic style in characters, environment, boss fights, armor, and [most] cash shop outfits.+ Incredible boss fight music+ Thrilling gameplay that involves maneuvering around boss movements. [My FAVORITE aspect of this game!]+ Break off system that gives boss hunting a new meaning+ Very unique differences between each starting character's play style+ Breaking armor and revealing [cash-purchased] inner armor is mucho sexy.+ Community still has very nice people near the start of the game. Just very hard to find.+ Paladin & Dark Knight transformations are very epic to pull out in times of need.+ Dynamic environment - Barrels, crates, and other things break when struck or thrown.+ Erotic inner armor designs. (Con: They all cost money to permanently own.)+ Coloring armors and outfits. (Con: Costs money, again... & many people just make their armors look ridiculous with neon bright colors that step out of the game's original art style.)+ In-game marketplace is very dynamic (Con: takes weeks of waiting on selling at highs and buying at lows = ridiculous amount of time investment)+ Nice movesets and combos that give different versatility during combat.Cons:- They released a Sword Art Online Kirito outfit that still has a bug with the coat flapping and humping your leg. People who paid $35 for this outfit can't even put this thing on due to comments from other players. It seems that they are planning on moving on and ignoring this issue. (FINALLY fixed after more than a year!*)- Plenty of elitists.- Very buggy game. Lots of issues. Not very stable.- Lag becomes a big issue when timing precise and accurate dodge mechanics. The system does not give you the benefit of the doubt when you've begin a dodge but computer skips several frames of it.- Enhancement & Enchanting systems are batshit silly. Don't even try it. (see other reviews)- Outfit and armor appendages clip through the insides a lot, but may not irritate some players.- Someone is always looking at your equipment to make sure they are better than you. Then they act very happy on boats when they see that they've got no competition in racking up damage dealt to the boss. (Results screen shows top damage)- Paladin & Dark Knight path levels take forever to level up. It becomes dismissed when a player finds out how much time it requires to reach the 2nd transformation.- Event exclusive items are mostly, if not all, timed crap. No joy in getting them. - When dying or coloring things in the Avatar shop, the light does NOT match the actual environment. Very possible to select an offset color that only looks good under strong light.- Community is filled with many naive people. Immature. Often sides with guild members and friends in ganging up and bullying other players.- Players who have been treated unfairly by Nexon customer service and pathetic compensation are left to fade away with no recognition of the event by other players.- The server screws everyone when an event attracts waves of Vindictus players to come back. Especially the quest dialogue reveals that it has a loading time. (Seriously... this is such an inefficient way of processing game information.)- Very limited end game armor options. All end game armors cost too much money and are excluded to only those that can grind enough money to get it. (again, ridiculous time investment that does not reward actual amount of time spent. depends on RNG -- with very low odds of getting rare drops)- ... This can keep going. The cons are abysmal.I hope this gives good info for what players will possibly deal with when picking this game up. It's one of those games that I can only play with a single friend or two. It is definitely not a game I can recommend to most people. I can only continue to play this game by myself (and sometimes with a friend) because it is ultimately a very lonely experience for someone who is casual but still loves certain parts of this game.After reading a few of the top reviews: Hiding armors and other enjoyable features for cash shop promotions? Seriously? No love given, no support received.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This is a very polished, super fun co-op hack-n-slash "instance based" MMO in the vein of Phantasy Star Online. There's your common area/hub, you accept missions, set up/join a party (or solo) and head off into closed levels where you proceed to beat the snot out of a ton of enemies. And the brawling is really fun. Nice variety of character classes (unfortunately gender locked; statistically, there have to be a TON of dudes playing as hot girls), and all have different fighting styles, and the Source-powered destruction adds a lot to the fights. It's super fun!It's all Free to Play, from what I have seen. All the actual content - the story, the missions, the sidequests, etc. - is attainable. Some is gonna need some grinding, but it's alleviated by the multiplayer, as are most monotonous tasks in games. It's all f2p  except for cosmetic items, as it should be. But they ARE pricey, and they unfortunately have options for 7-day and 30-day rentals, which seem more reasonably priced. But to get the permanent options, it's gonna be pricey. It's a good game, and it's worth spending some money on -- DevCat made a really cool game, and they deserve to be compensated for their work. But man, this model is harsh. I'm talking $8 for a SHIRT or PAIR of pants, permanently. Woof. Still, whatever, that's easy to avoid. Just play with a bland character, and enjoy the actual mission content. Then buy something rarely. Be responsible with your money (keep a ceiling in mind, and don't go past it) and you'll totally enjoy this game if you enjoy beating up fantasy creatures with buddies. Vindictus is a rad game, but Nexon needs to work on their payment models for future games. Recommended overall though.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2012
												You know how TERA calls itself "the first true action MMO"? Vindictus does it better, and it's been around longer.Combat is purely action-based, so much so that it feels more like God of War than World of Warcraft. It's tons of fun to slaughter hordes of enemies, and absurdly satisfying to take down the tough boss at the end of the dungeon. You can do all this by yourself, or party up with strangers or friends for a co-op experience.This game is very skill-based, and while upgrading your in-game gear and abilities matters, the person who does the most damage to a boss usually depends on who knows the boss's attack patterns best. And with enough skill and patience, you could even defeat a nightmarish raid boss all by yourself! It's not EASY, but it's certainly doable.But if you're going to play this game, I have one piece of advice for you: enhance and enchant your gear with caution. If you go too high (past +8 enhancement or Rank 9 enchants), your gear might break.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												     If you're tired of WOW hotkey type combat, this is probably the game you're looking for. The combat system alone makes the game worth playing, it's actually a shame you don't see this type of combo system in MMO's very often, as this makes it alot more interesting. It's very addicting, and you'll be spending days late game trying to catch those elusive raid drops. However, as with many Nexon games it survives off of microtransactions, as paying for certain aesthetics and even some game changing items are in the game, this being one of it's major flaws. It IS possible to get through the game without spending a penny, just very difficult.      The exp gain rate is okay compared to most MMOs, only getting truly painful up in your 65-80 level range. But by the time you're level 70, getting to 80 isn't always on your mind and it's best to just ease into the level. Overall it's a VERY good game despite it's flaws, yet every game has flaws of it's own.

												Played this game when it was still pretty new. Still think it's awesome til this day. However there's two things I really have a hate for and it made me completely stop playing it:1-Cash Shop: not really a problem if you don't intend to buy things with real money but if you do, cash items are quite expensive for it's price. Once you get into the higher levels however, you'll see people making parties with demands meaning they'll kick you out if you don't meet their standards. This happens way too much.This game tends to be a grind fest because of the very low drop rates of rare items but I still had fun grinding.Try this game out if you want something new than a general mmorpg. But if you want to make this game a hardcore hobby (like I did), I highly recommend joining a guild or make trustworthy and awesome friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22
												You shouldn't invest your time into this game. Many of the players that are still here can't leave because of time investment, money investment or friends. Not to say you shouldn't play this game if you have friends on it, just saying you shouldn't invest too much. Another reason the population is so low is because of false ban accusations by black cipher which has banned multiple innocent accounts and heavily invested players, so you could also get banned for having a non-harmful program running in the background. Vindictus is just like a crazy girlfriend, you better focus on her or she'll cut your♥♥♥♥♥♥off :).You have 2 chances. If you get falsey banned once and get it repealed, that's a strike against your account. If it happens again, you're perma banned regardless if it was legit or not. They don't care, they just want to be right and they refuse to change their policy on this and have now killed all fansites and many of my friends :D. I'm just sitting here patiently waiting to see if they do the same to me, since I'm a whale.The game is best known for its combat style and "dress up simulator" graphics aren't too bad for an old game either.Since the game is instance based this game relies on the player base to host parties to run missions. Frames (fps) are almost nonexistent here(maybe overexaggerated, but never fully 60fps). It's an old game and they don't do much to make the game run better on official servers.Aside from that, as a new player it is hard to gear up unless you have help from friends, dedicate alot of time or spend nx. If you don't mind the struggle then this is no big deal to you. I think with some heavy spending, it took me a month to hit "end game" gear. Aside from spending, farming for gold was difficult unless I had alot of time on my hands. Maybe 3hours+ for raids and farmable missions. Even then, it's all rng. Especially the part about getting banned :).The management for NA version of this game isn't looked to kindly by the community really. The management team doesn't seem to really care about anything relative to the game other than bug fixes and sales.Many of the players that do spend money on this game (and I mean like a hefty amount) have expressed their displeasure with how sales have been with this game. Each and every sale (mainly gachas) they have done nothing but just make the experience worse and not worth your money.At this point, to me, it just feels like they're milking the game as much as they can before it dies. For me I don't want to spend money only to see the game die sooner than necessary. Many of the days I'm on this game, I wonder if even we'll have everything that Korea's server has one day. But that won't happen because they change up alot of the things with the sales that korean's get in outfitter shop while we're stuck with a gacha. Then they tell us that "oh, but this is how the koreans did it" When it's clear BS. That's just one example that I could think of.As a player, having these kinds of occurences and views towards them...I wouldn't want anyone to be a part of that. A company that provides a service but doesn't really care if you're satisfied with the experience. Basically polite scamming and sometimes actual scamming with some of the sales they do. With all the feedback they've been given, they don't do anything really to fix it or please the people that pay or the casual people that do spend every now and then.Side note: I'm a collector, so I like to have multiple vanity and costumes that the game has to offer (only the ones I like). I started late so I didn't have everything from the beginning. I requested for them to bring back SQ as many other people seemed to have wanted too. They did. Another thing I really wanted for them to bring back was elchulus wings. They brought it back in a black friday gacha and nothing to exchange with so it was all rng. I rolled them, got costumes I already had so I had to throw them on alts, characters I don't even play. Wasted about $800 trying to get it on 2 different characters. Because they decided to limit the boxes to 10 purchases a day per account. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												Before we begin, I implore you to go to the VindictusManual website and read everything that is there to see, and understand the scope of these issues.Alright. Here it goes.I've played Vindictus off and on for the last few years- And while I have many things to say about the combat system, community resources, and lack of community driven additions to the game, (to give players a place to show off all that amazing gear they've acquired, or simply create a group of friends to enjoy the game with-) it'll have to wait for another review.Vindictus is managed by a company called Nexon, a company infamous for a lack of care for it's communities. Over the last couple years, Nexon North America has never ceased it's tireless crusade against it's OWN playerbase. Demonizing and attacking playermade sites and online resources, banning any players that act irregularly on their anti-hack system, regardless of the fact that the bloody thing detects things like RUNESCAPE and OTHER NEXON GAMES AS POTENTIAL HACKS. Boom. Autoban.The people running the community forum are simply put: Cowards. They lack the ability to deal with a community that at one point, was growing. They ban anyone that posts a complaint, attempts to find redemption for daring to use another program while playing their game. Hundreds of dollars down the drain.The frightening part about that isn't that Vindictus players are losing hundreds of dollars when they're banned. The concerning part is WHY they have spent hundreds of dollars on the game. Vindictus, like most of their games allows you to purchase in game benefits that drive your character forward through progression, and I'm not talking level progression, I'm talking combat benefits and dozens of automatic revives on the spot to let you solo any content if you just have enough real-life cash to pay for it. You can purchase entire sets of end-game gear from the in game shot, and the gear enchancement system at the endgame content is so bloody toxic, considering you need to roll a dice 15 times, and if it fails 1/15 of those times, you must start from scratch and find a new piece of gear for that slot. I believe this isn't healthy for the game, and diminishes the rewards and prestige that might accompany actual success in game. If you're truly interested in playing Vindictus, or as it's known in the east 'Mabinogi Heroes' then be sure to do so on another server. Nexon has never cared for it's playerbase, and likely never will. It's worth a shot, but if I've turned off even one of you, then I find this a success.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												This is a TL;DR pros and cons list for the lazy. Everyone else, the full review is below.NOTE: My hours on Steam are about a quarter or less of the hours I have on this game.PROS:-Decent graphics-Interesting art style-Unique character and world design-INCREDIBLE combat system-Interesting story and characters-Wealth of content-Decent endgame-No game impacting microtransactionsCONS:-Poor customer support-Could be optimized better-Limited character customization-Huge learning curve into lategameFULL REVIEW: After playing Vindictus for 5 years, I think I'm qualified for this review. Vindictus is a hack-and-slash MMO made by Nexon. Normally, the Nexon part would put me off (despite the fact I also played Combat Arms for many years). But with Vindictus, they managed to achieve something special. As far as massively multiplayer games go, it is a unique experience. The engine is quite unlike any other MMO I've played. The graphics are polished and nice to look at, and the controls are simple and intuitive. This is helped along by the absolutely wonderful combat system, which plays more like Devil May Cry than a simple MMO. The amount of content is enough to keep any junkie going for a long time, with 10 different classes, a long, mostly well written story with multiple over-arching plots, and a thriving, pleasant community. The aesthetic is unique among fantasy games as well, being more akin to 17th century Europe rather than an over the top fantasy world with sprawling glass skyscrapers and whatnot. The design in the characters and weapons/armour is less flashy, and more functional (with exceptions, of course). The cutscenes are few and far in between, which is fine by me. They are clunky and don't fit particularly well. The voice acting isn't stellar, either. Outside of cutscenes, none of the characters ever actually appear in game. Instead, when interacting with characters, a drawn portrait of them greets you. This is another unique aspect of the game that I enjoy. Their face changes depending on what mood they're in, and they look like believable people. Over all, Vindictus is a wonderful and unique experience that has stayed strong over the years, and will continue to do so.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2012
												Vindictus is a very fun game but you need to be prepared for what you are getting yourself into.  This is an action MMO and probably the best of its kind.  There is no real world to explore and not a whole lot to do outside of dungeon crawling.  Also, be prepared for a very heavy grind and long farming sessions.  Also the company that runs the game kind of blows.  Also, the community is just so-so.  There are a lot of elitists in this game.  A lot. But the game itself really isn't terrible at all and if you're a fan of Blade & Soul, Tera or any other action MMO you'll feel right at home.  But keep in mind that this game is very challenging and if you want to do any of the higher end-game content, you'll either have to spend hundreds of dollars in the cash shop or farm til your eyes bleed.  The amount of customization is great in this game and you can make your character look amazing, but again, it all comes down to how much money you want to throw into the cash shop.  The game isn't pay-to-win, however, and there's plenty of opportunity for glory to those who work hard enough.  Just enjoy the ride and find a nice guild to call home.  Know what you're getting into ahead of time and there won't be any surprises.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The game's model promotes investing cash into gear to stay ahead of the curve just to meet requirements needed to even beat the content. Attack vs skill had more of a balance in the long ago past but the scale definitely favours your stats these days. The bosses have become closer to punching bags than enemies with little fulfillment outside the worthless e-peen of damage rankings in end results. I will still recommend it if you find a nice group of friends to play with since the game can also be a good social experience within guilds. And while it's harder to play casually, the option is still there (might get kicked for low stats). It will depend on what type of person you are and what you want. My funnest times were yelling at random people while wearing shorts and a bunny hat, and that's a successful casual experience in my book. Maybe yours will be to have powerful gear for your battles, but try not to get too caught up in it.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												I've spent almost 6 hours just trying to get this game to run. As soon as I fixed one launching error, another would pop up. I reinstalled the game twice and even after I had checked the file integrity immediatly after installing, it said there were issues. So I had to go through the game's files and delete random .avi files and rewrite dates in text files to be current. After finally getting into the main menu and excited to start playing, I can't even connect to a server. I tried all of the whopping 3 servers to try to play and none worked. The game looks fun to mess about with until you get to the endgame grind, but with the overwhelming amount of flaws with just launching and entering the game, coupled with many other people's frustrations with customer service (which you will be bound to run in to eventually) and game design revolving around in-game purchases, I can't recommend it in the least.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2012
												Gorgeous hack-n-slash MMO with unique heroes with diverse play styles.  Story line is thought out fairly well, its not bad.  Community consists of your standard nexderpity derps.If you wanted to play a live action game similar to Kingdom Hearts or Devil May Cry in a MMO atmosphere, Vindictus is your best bet.  There is no other MMO game that offers such fluid combo based hack-n-slash live action fighting then Vindictus.Nexon's direction with this game; management, content, cash shop, and events, is the only thing that really brings down this game.  Far too often you're going to run into a potentially game breaking experience on Nexon's end.  Laggy servers, game crashing bugs after each patch, and time based events that do not work outright.Bottom line, if you can bring yourself to ignore the extras the game has to offer for your first 30 levels and only do main quest lines,  I would seriously consider giving this game a try.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												In much the same way that Just Cause 2 could be "loosely based on" Don Quixote, Vindictus (or Mabinogi: Heroes for you non-Americans) is loosely based on the Mabinogion, a set of Welsh mythology. This interpretation is centered around Korean anime people in either chain-mail lingerie or pots-and-pans armor wielding giant battle-scythes and tree trunks: so basically, everything you'd expect from 14th century pre-Christian Celtic folklore.In this version, Pwyll is named "Lann", Pryderi is "Kai", Rhiannon is "Evie", Branwen is "Fiona", and Bendigeidfran is "Karok". Instead of the original episodic tales that feature the relationships between characters, their romances, conflicts, struggles and occasional deus ex machina magic, you just grind for levels, pay microtransactions and commit a lot of animal cruelty to dog people, vampires, blood jellies, golems and dragons. Also, they wiped my character a few months ago, so ♥♥♥♥ Nexon.Overall: 4/5
