content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I've probably clocked a thousand hours on this game before I started playing on steam (and a lot more recently if Steam let me log in multiple accounts). Don't let the RPG tag deceive you. Vindictus is not like any other MMORPG: It's a hack and slash dungeon crawler that's extremely fast paced. If you're coming to this game expecting an open-world point-and-click, then you'll be disappointed. The first 60 levels are quite easy but fairly boring to play through. Most dungeons can be soloed. Two of the episodes are simply reskins of the previous ones -- a prevalent problem that dissuades many from continuing. Once you reach level 60 is where all the action begins, where the raid bosses are. You face Titan, Thor, Glas Ghaibhleann: titanic monsters that can two-shot you if you're not quick on your feet (or fingers!). All of those bosses you see in pictures are straight from screenshots, unlike cinematic clips that most rpgs put on their cover. The game, however, requires a lot of commitment to reach end-game. So find a guild, play with friends, and enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Rare that you will find an MMO that plays remotely simmilar to this. Controls and Feels like Dynasty Warriors. Great to play in co-op with freinds. Beware of a few things: it uses a Class System with limited character customisation. You will have to leap past an initial pay-wall and buy a dazzel-em dead pack if you want a fully customized character. In fact just straight up beware of all the DLC, it's a free to play game and DLC costs a boatload, and much of  the actually useful stuff is upright temporary.And Also beware of the fact that the game's graphical, lighting, and gameplay quality will amp up as you progress through the game, and won't really begin to shine until halfway through season 1 of the game when you enter Rocheste. Nearly all the gameplay balances came in the form of Character updates, and the early levels have not been overhauled yet (but apparently character and armor textures are about to be updated to higher res, so you have something to look forwards to).Otherwise, it's a great game that is worth a shot. And might just help tide you over till Black Dessert comes out.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Alright, lemme get something straight. I love Vindictus and the sequel, Mabinogi (Which I might cover in a future review). They're great games, I play them for hours at a time, mostly on the NXLauncher. However, with the god-awful customer support I see constantly, and the recent issues with the Nexon Game Launcher, I can't even play this game any more. I've been looking through the net for possible solutions to it, but none work or have clear steps for what I should do. I cannot even log in through Steam now, and the NXLauncher isn't working either. It's a shame, I loved this game and played off and on with delight; now it's just a burden attempting to try and load up. AAAnyway, let's move past my personal complaints and get specific.-PRO-+Great Quality and Graphics+Plenty of Hackin' and Slashin'+Lots of Characters to try out with their own playstyle and weapons-CON--Customer support is garbage, you see plenty of reports on that everywhere related to NEXON-Character Creation at start is also trash; limited options force you to eventually buy Karma Koin to get those needed hairstyle changes and dye-Not much else to do other than Combat. You can cook and make clothes, but it's not really worth it when you can just go and buy what you want in the MarketPlace ingameOverall, I'd say 5/10. I wouldn't reccomend it to too many people, but it suited me just fine while I could still play it.Do let me know if I missed something good or bad; I would gladly edit and put it here.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Vindictus is a hack n slash type game with a rich story (if you like reading through long text scenes). First off: If you're looking for a F2P MMO that you don't want to put money into: Turn away. Right now. Pros:The game itself is fun when you're playing with a group of friends and helping eachother out.The gameplay is very fun, "open combat" (no targeting, free roam fighting) Think of something like Kingdom Hearts combat in a sense. With the lack of a lock on system, which isn't really needed for this type of game.(As of now) There are a nice diverse set of characters to play, and it is fun to try out each character for different styles of gameplay.The leveling is very guided and easy to do, just follow the story and you'll pretty much level up from 1 to end game in at least a month or so of moderate play. If you play nothing but this game you could get to end game content within a few days.Cons:Hosting is a very rare ability which very few people can handle.This game runs on only ONE core. The more cores you have, the possibly less stability you'll have with the game.Duo cores run this game like gods. (If you have around 3 to 3.5 Ghz)The community in this game can be very unforgiving. Elite-ists make it hard for new players to enjoy the game (with "boat restrictions" requiring people to have a set amount of stats to join them). The community sets the bar high for most end game content, making it hard for new players to enjoy all the game as to offer, and learn how to play the game/fight, in terms of big raids and fights.--(Refering also to the comment above) The game requires a lot of "luck" and "time" to be able to play end game content. Even though now it is easy to meet bare minimum requirements with a certain Level 70 set, it is still hard to find accepting people. (Also the cap at the time of this review is level 80. Plans to raise the level cap are in the air apparently.)End game equipment is very hard to obtain, because the drops needed for End game equipment are very rare. When these do end up dropping, the more wise decision is to sell it (for casual play that is). It is not impossible, but it is very time consuming and tedious to collect all of the neccesarry materials for end game items.--(Follow up) "End" end game equipment, items previous to the "now" end game equipment, is actually obtainable through literally just playing the game. These "end" end game equipments are helpful in meeting newer boat requirements but are also tedious to work towards (Ex: Apoc sets you need "Blue tears" to make 3 out of 5 parts of the set. The tear can be bought in a "seal shop" for roughly 334 seals. To get these seals you need to run one-a-day raids. You can obtain up to 12 seals a day. If you dedicate yourself, you can get one tear after 28 days of straight raids. If you have no luck in buying a tear, or if you never get a drop to use toward the set, that is 84 days of Raid grinding for a Level 70 set. Brutal sounding, right?)Overall, after my four or five years of playing this game (since release) I'd have to say:If you're looking to play with a group of friends diligently, this is a good game to play.If you're looking for a game to casually play by yourself, it could be fun at first, and then very frustrating toward end game.If you're looking for a game to play hardcore in and out, prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥for the hardships you may encounter. Find a guild to join or something.If you want to just play this game because you think it looks good, Don't stick to it you might get disappointed by end game community.SEASON 3 UPDATE:Season 3 has made the game much more forgiving, but not to the point of handing you the game. It is much easier for players to build end game gear without making impossible leaps of luck. Rare materials are easily accessible through the revamped Seal Shop and it is much easier to make the gears needed to progress through the game.This does not mean you will not hit a point where spending money will never be a need. This game still, almost requires, some amount of money to be put into it. How much you spend is really up to you.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												This game is fun, at first, but you need to understand this game is pay to play (not pay to win).So for starters.This game is fantastic at the start, your char and moves feel great and monster and environments are interesting. However, as you get to endgame the game violently shifts to pay to live...  Meaning, you will have to spend real money on health pots, goddess graces, and other items to keep you alive because if you attempt to to use the free itmes you will get hit, and when you get hit you will lose more hp than you would of gained drinking the potion.Additionally, you will need a beefy computer and internet connection to host games because this game is Peer to Peer connections ... meaning Lag is an issue.  Combat at endgame is all about twitch combat and if your connection sucks you will be eating the ground before you know it.There is no function support for this game.  Meaning Nexon the publisher and Devcat the developer both suck at their jobs and do not respond to support tickets. Endgame hurts ... Ive been paying for years and have only gotten about 10 endgame gear drops ... so you have to grind and sell items on the Market Place to make money to buy the rare drops.You need stupidly high dps for endgame as bosses have a defense limit you have to break or you will be doing effectivly no dps ... so this leads to elitiest boats.There is no balance in the game.  I have a Hammer Fiona ... I do stupidly low dps in endgame because thats just how things work now .... I refuse to switch because I love hammers and unless Devcat rebalances the clas or adds new abilities thats the way it goes.Kai's are OP as all getout ... their mobility and ranged dps means they can avoid most boss spam and continue high dps, so if you are looking for a fun class ... they are your money ticket.There are in game purchases ... and they are overpiced.They key to surviving in this game is 2 things... find good friends and a good social guild.... you need to have fun or this game will rub you the wrong way hard.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												    Let me start off with one of my most common comment about this game, "Vindictus, is like playing a 60 dollar RPG game, but you can use the 60 dollars for asthetics". I've played this game since it was in closed beta, and I still remember the old days playing with my old group, dungeon crawling, figuring out how to strategize against bosses, and continously scream at Blood Lord. This game is a great MMO, especially for the crowds that are trying to get into them. I say this especially because there are other MMOs that people try to get into and absolutely lose faith in them afterwards. They usually fall under 3 major causes, difficulty, complexity, and graphics.     Difficulty is pretty straight forward, and some games completely screw over the player. By trying to constantly challenge the player at the beginning of the game, players will eventually lose faith and stop. Making a game too easy, will also make the game less appealing. Vindictus finds a nice way to easily situate the player, get them used to their characters, and begin to show them their true potential through skills like Gliding Fury, Counter Attack, Clash, or Cross Stance/Cut.    Complexity is really how complex the gameplay can be. You don't want a game that makes everything too simple to the player. A constant click click click, and you beat the game, is really not the best way to allure players.  On the other extreme, people don't want a game that will have them alternating several keys at once in order to just attack. In games such as vindictus, it's imperial to make sure the player is having fun, not always on edge because he/she is constantly panicking during "basic" fights. Vindictus is basic enough to keep a player at attention, and at the same time is complex and very fun. Nothing makes me happier than to grab a kobold or gnoll and slaying them in multiple fashions.     Graphics is one of the most debated topics in my time of playing games. One one side, it's great to have good graphics because it makes it seem realistic and provides a surreal environment. On the other hand, you don't one graphic or else only those with high definition graphic cards could play it. Vindictus is a perfect example of games who found an equilibrium, as the realistic models and stunning graphics make it seem all too real to be true.     Vindictus overall is a great game, and I hope that it gets as much love as I have for it. It may have it's flaws but it does make up for it in several departments. One major concern is always the Nexon Depot, as you can buy things using real life money. However all of that is trivial, and does not get in the way of you beating the game, unlike other games that require you to spend 5 dollars to unlock their membership mode. I say yet again, it's like a 60 dollar MMO, but free.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Ok, so I just recently got this game on steam, but I've been playing it for over two years now.This game has some very addicting combat mechanics, which are very fast paced later on in the game. There are many character types to choose from, each offering a different playstyle. Along with great gameplay, this game also offers good graphics, and a somewhat destructable environment which u can take to your advantage during some enemy encounters. With that said however this game does have its drawbacks. The majority of the player base is focused towards the later part of the game, which would be fine, but this leaves those at earlier stages left to fend forthemselves, making progrssion lonely, and boring at times. Once you do get to the later parts of the game you soon realise that attaining certain armor and weapons almost impposible as extremely poor drop rates, and insanely high prices means only a lucky few will aquire said items. But don't be discouraged, because even with deacent gear, and sharpened skills you can still play and enjoy every aspect of this game.To conclude, this game certainly isnt perfect, however, if you find a good guild and make some new friends, you will have a great time slashing and bashing monesters and look good doing it. The gameplay will keep you coming back, and there will always be more improvements to make to the characters you play.If your at least curious about this game I highly recomend you try it, you might be pleasantly surprised. I'll see you in there. :)

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Please note: As it may say 0.5 hours on my steam account. I played this game through the nexon site. This was way before Vindictus went on steam :3.I loved this game...when it first came out. It was absolutley amazing. And the community was awesome. Everyone worked as a team. The grinding was was not tedious.THE COMBAT WAS SO AMAZING! Every move was precise and the physics were just out standing.  .And I say this because every battle was different. The crafting was also worth the time. All and all back then...I would have giving it a 9/10.Fast Forward today.No, I can not reccomend this game. I decided to get back into it and see whats changed. And to be honest...it sucks.I got spammed with bots and people weren't very nice anymore. NO one worked as a team in my experience. This game had a lot of potential. And I feel like some of it..isnt there anymore. Combat is still decent. But what annoys me is the damage indicators... That really annoys me. Because before. You hit an enemy and it's like.. Damn, I must've hit him hard. And made you wanna hit this enemy more. Now with damage indicators its like... 20 damage... Well damn. I dont feel that immersed anymore. And the list goes on and on.MY verdict...You can play this game. But...In my opinion, its not really worth the time and effort

												I reached a point where I find myself looking to the free-to-play mmo's for a source of entertainment. This is how I came across Vindictus.It's looks like it should be a fine, top of the line mmo; but with one flaw that breaks the game before the player actually starts. I installed the game, and was met by not one, but seven launcher crashes in a row. On attempt number eight., I was faced with a long♥♥♥♥♥background instalation that made me think the game crashed again. Attempt number nine actually got me into the game, but as I tried to connect to the server, the game crashed entirely. Three more attempts just to get into the game resulted in the same crash. Hell, even a personal friend with a recently updated PC even crashed as much as I did trying to get in.Take my word for it, the game is not worth the amount of time it will take just to start the bloody launcher.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												    Let me start off with one of my most common comment about this game, "Vindictus, is like playing a 60 dollar RPG game, but you can use the 60 dollars for asthetics". I've played this game since it was in closed beta, and I still remember the old days playing with my old group, dungeon crawling, figuring out how to strategize against bosses, and continously scream at Blood Lord. This game is a great MMO, especially for the crowds that are trying to get into them. I say this especially because there are other MMOs that people try to get into and absolutely lose faith in them afterwards. They usually fall under 3 major causes, difficulty, complexity, and graphics.     Difficulty is pretty straight forward, and some games completely screw over the player. By trying to constantly challenge the player at the beginning of the game, players will eventually lose faith and stop. Making a game too easy, will also make the game less appealing. Vindictus finds a nice way to easily situate the player, get them used to their characters, and begin to show them their true potential through skills like Gliding Fury, Counter Attack, Clash, or Cross Stance/Cut.    Complexity is really how complex the gameplay can be. You don't want a game that makes everything too simple to the player. A constant click click click, and you beat the game, is really not the best way to allure players.  On the other extreme, people don't want a game that will have them alternating several keys at once in order to just attack. In games such as vindictus, it's imperial to make sure the player is having fun, not always on edge because he/she is constantly panicking during "basic" fights. Vindictus is basic enough to keep a player at attention, and at the same time is complex and very fun. Nothing makes me happier than to grab a kobold or gnoll and slaying them in multiple fashions.     Graphics is one of the most debated topics in my time of playing games. One one side, it's great to have good graphics because it makes it seem realistic and provides a surreal environment. On the other hand, you don't one graphic or else only those with high definition graphic cards could play it. Vindictus is a perfect example of games who found an equilibrium, as the realistic models and stunning graphics make it seem all too real to be true.     Vindictus overall is a great game, and I hope that it gets as much love as I have for it. It may have it's flaws but it does make up for it in several departments. One major concern is always the Nexon Depot, as you can buy things using real life money. However all of that is trivial, and does not get in the way of you beating the game, unlike other games that require you to spend 5 dollars to unlock their membership mode. I say yet again, it's like a 60 dollar MMO, but free.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Unless you like playing a single player game with an MMO grind, I would not recommend this to anyone who likes games for the community.Vindictus' Achilles' heel is its match-making system. This game is a lobby game that provides a market, PVE, and PVP, yet you can't join other people's PVE stages in-session like Warframe and you're not even allowed to do something productive as your PVE party forms like in Dungeon Fighter Online. In Vindictus, as you form your party, you are confined in an instanced area that provides nothing productive other than a punching dummy, a general vendor, and a mailbox. You end up getting people who don't want to form parties hence people who can't get parties. For comparision, imagine being forced to do nothing in WoW as you queue up: you can't work on professions, browse the auction house, go do other quests, or even travel. How often would the WoW's community queue with such an absurd confinement? Warframe was pretty shallow when I played it and DFO Internaltional was shutdown, yet they at least didn't waste your time as you queued for parties.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I find that what really matters about this game is the fact that you can just sit around at a campfire, relax, and just forget about all the harshness of the dreaded Nexon service, all the harshness of the high level "18K att" boats.  Sometimes people don't see the true value of this game, how it mimics real life and turns it into something that goes on everyone's screen.  There wouldn't be time for worrying if relaxing was the main point.  But no, everyone strives to become the best at everything in this game, it's a simple human quality.I'll go right into the main value of this game.  It is the idea of wanting to become stronger, and fighting enemies that are massive and may never be defeated.  It is the simple risk of always being on the brink of death, yet always coming back by the use of a phoenix feather, that drives us to keep on fighting.  We upgrade our equipment and wail in the painful days of grinding dungeons for that one enchant scroll.  And when we have maxed out our character, it seems as if there is no purpose after that, seeing as the low levels hold a bias against the high levels and vice versa.  We want to help others, but it seems as if the low levels deny us that permission.  We always constantly want everything, to max out to +15, all of that stuff.     All in all, hack and slashing is extremely entertaining to partake in, but in the end it's just going to lead up to the feared question of "what should I do next?".   The main plotline of this game is to fight for the hope of achieveing "Utopia" for ridding the fomors of the human land.  Since the goddess has forsaken all humans, and they are left to fight, this makes it seem as if all hope is lost.  This game teaches a great lesson such that Utopia will never be achieved from playing this game.  It is for the purpose of escaping from reality, but this game will always make you feel empty once you reach level 60+.  The game becomes hell in a way, as all there is to do is raid and / or help others that are lower level.  The main point of the game becomes a game of chance and the need for gold.  But the lesson of this game, in my own words, is to teach the player that sometimes sitting at a simple campfire and having friends to converse with is the best Utopia even when in a time of needing the best equipment and armor.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												This game really caught my eye for one reason.  It was actually Free to Play, unlike every other MMO known to mankind.  The only things you actually have to pay for aren't necessary for completion of the game.  I haven't actually paid for anything yet in the game.  There's also offers to earn NX, the ingame currency.  So, if you want, you could complete the entire game without touching your wallet.  The gameplay is simple, yet addictive.  While some runs may need to be repeated to reach the next level(and unlock the next quest), the boss battles can be challenging, and good fun.  Along with these are "Oaths of Honor", which are small challenges to make the run more difficult(Example, complete the quest under a set time, or use no potions).  You can jump into battle with one of the six characters in the game.  Do you want to charge in swords-a-blazing?  Snipe your foes with a longbow?  Crush everyone with a Cestus?  The choice is yours.Anyway, I hope this review has helped you decide on this game(And hopefully, I got it accurate xD).

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Beautiful game. Amazing storyline. Creative monsters. Prelude to my second favorite game made by Nexon.This game has the most beautiful artwork and concepts of armor I have ever seen. Each character is crafted as their own. While the facial features might be the same for all characters, it really doesn't matter when you can personalize any way you want from skin tone to make-up to even under armor. The characters move so in tune with their weapons nothing seems unnatural.The storyline is fantastic, especially because this is all a prelude to Nexon's Mabinogi. This game is much more serious than Mabinogi and it certainly gives you a break from the care-free enviroment of it, which is sometimes nice. The storyline I can keep track of pretty well with easy to remember names and (regretably) a very small map with 2 towns, one you are in 90% of the time. The monsters are your usual monsters, but with a little twist and have such amazing graphics and design to them. Gnolls are transformed and given clever names, ranks, titles and even abilities and stray from your usual dog-man creature. Nexon really nailed it on this one when it comes to 3D monster art.As I said before, this game leads up to Nexon's Mabinogi (which is another great game by them). This clears up some of the plot to Mabinogi and this is all around a good plot on it's own.This game is absolutely perfect for a gamer who loves running dungeons with an amazing looking character. If you aren't downloading this now, you should.

												More boring than it advertises itself to be.Generally, I've played alot of MMOs and this isn't really that bad. It DOES take alot of grinding though, but not too much. You will get swamped in sidequests if you DARE talk to any npcs outside of your main quest.Many things in the game aren't told/hinted about, which was kinda of annoying. Nobody wants to spend 20 minutes of wiki reading to realize you need to go to a new town in order to learn how to make weapons, although the stations to craft the weapon are in the first town you go in.Fluid combat, decent graphics, hefty rewards for staying loyal.Non-generic bosses (mostly), annoying drop rates, grinding.XP doesn't come too slowly, which is a good thing.Every class is arguably balanced.Overally it's a good game, as long as you're used to grinding.

												Great game, I love it!  Vindictus is very well balanced, and not even slightly pay-to-win.  Though the economy is a bit difficult to wrap your brain around at first, but just take a look at a guide or two and it's easy as pie to get LOTS of money REALLY fast.Gameplay is simple, yet satisfying in a way; though you will have to go on the occasional grind for mission completion.  Good leveling system and unique skills to unlock, it's really easy to figure out and play.  I'd definitely encourage anyone to play this game!Edit:  It has come to my attention that I am not nearly as experienced enough in this game as I thought I was.  The above description really only applies until some of the later levels (about lvl 60), and the economy begins to  crash on you:  weapons and equipment are over priced, not enough people are selling/buying resources to craft higher level equipment for cheaper, way too much grinding, and whatnot until you have to result to using real money to progress through the game.Basically, this game is only worth playing if you like grinding and probably giving up later in the game.  Fun at first, not so much later.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2012
												Wow, I remember this one from years ago.  It has one of the most fully-developed physics engines of any MMO I've ever seen.  The four characters (I remember when it was only three, and it may be five soon) all played very differently and honestly, the only one I couldn't really get into playing was Lann (the dual swordsman).  Lastly, a very good story for an MMO.I feel that its only major flaw is that it's of the hub-and-mission style of MMOs - probably done so they can ensure the physics engine is handled correctly.  However, that flaw is tremendous in a scenario where the 'hub' is an actual area where the players gather, because the lag gets horrendous.Unfortunately this is one of those games that's marred by the company that holds it - Nexon.  Nexon has NO idea how to deal with any kind of customer support and is notorious for pay-to-win problems.  The latter doesn't actually rear its head NEARLY as much as it did in DFO, but there are still shades of it.Overall, my bad experiences with Nexon are the main thing preventing me from recommending this.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												7/10As far as gameplay goes, it has the most unique and fluid combat system of any MMO that I have played. The battle system trumps C9, and even Black Desert; a 2016 'modern' game. There are a wide variety of genderlocked characters and playstyles to suit your needs. Learning your character is very fun, and encouraged. The game definitely supports your progress of learning the best way to play your character; especially in the Season 3 content which forces you to learn how to dodge and take less hits. Near endgame, it does get very grindy if you want better gear to do the endgame content, but level-wise, doing story content brings your character level approximately five levels under the cap. The story itself is terrible, but it has gotten slightly better with Season 3.Despite being an older game, I would say the graphics hold up to many modern games that have come out these past few years. There are many glitches in the game however, and the voice acting is terrible. Be ready to listen to the characters screech at each other when your party members don't esc the cutscenes.Now, the cash shop. I have seen many MANY people saying that Vindictus is a pay to win game, all over the forums and the comments of anything Vindictus ever posts. And I invite you to explain to me why you say this is a pay to win game. Nexon will literally throw free NX items at you like candy; especially merc pots and blessings. Events give enhancement runes and enchant runes. They've even given out free cosmetics and pets in the past. The only items that are pay to win in the game are the battle boxes, which if lucky, will give you a rare grade weapon material or weapon. Keep in mind that you need five of these rare grade materials in order to build a weapon. Also, if you want anything worthwhile from these boxes, you'll either have to be lucky or buy A LOT of these to even get anything good. Unless you're telling me that you're going to buy and spam merc pots in raids, I don't see this game being pay to win in any way. Learn your character and get good at the game. Gameplay is highly dependent on skill, and most of the items in the cash shop are for cosmetic purposes only or for giving you small benefits when enhancing/enchanting weapons.Now here's the bad. The company that owns it: Nexon. They are notorious for their complete lack of customer service and communication to the players. It has gotten better over the years, but it is still nowhere where it should be. If you play, expect to be hit with a few days of lag and bad servers before Nexon gets around to fixing it. Some bugs have been around for years and are STILL around. If something in the game breaks after an update, don't expect it to be fixed. New content gets released maybe five times a year. In between those long periods, events happen, but many of them are RNG or grind based events that serve little purpose to keeping you in the game. As of this review, the community is basically dead. These past few weeks, i've seen the board empty of raids, and have found it hard to gather enough people to even do raids when I am hosting missions. Now, keep in mind that this game is HIGHLY community based. Yes, if you're really good, you could solo everything if you wanted to. But most people can't solo and/or host, and need to rely on others for help. Which is why the decline in the community is so bad for the health of the game. It's a shame, since this game has so much potential and it's being run into the ground by an incompetent company. The only thing that keeps me coming back to this game are the updates and my friends that play. Other than that, Nexon provides you with no incentive to keep playing, which causes the death of a wonderful game due to sheer laziness on their part.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I reached a point where I find myself looking to the free-to-play mmo's for a source of entertainment. This is how I came across Vindictus.It's looks like it should be a fine, top of the line mmo; but with one flaw that breaks the game before the player actually starts. It was made by Nexon.Yes, the same Nexon that made the buggy as hell, hacker-infested Combat Arms.I decided to move past this, thinking Nexon got their act together, and decided to try the game for myself. I installed the game, and was met by not one, but seven launcher crashes in a row. On attempt number eight., I was faced with a long♥♥♥♥♥background instalation that made me think the game crashed again. Attempt number nine actually got me into the game, but as I tried to connect to the server, the game crashed entirely. Three more attempts just to get into the game resulted in the same crash. Hell, even a personal friend with a recently updated PC even crashed as much as I did trying to get in.Take my word for it, the game is not worth the amount of time it will take just to start the bloody launcher.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												This game really caught my eye for one reason.  It was actually Free to Play, unlike every other MMO known to mankind.  The only things you actually have to pay for aren't necessary for completion of the game.  I haven't actually paid for anything yet in the game.  There's also offers to earn NX, the ingame currency.  So, if you want, you could complete the entire game without touching your wallet.  The gameplay is simple, yet addictive.  While some runs may need to be repeated to reach the next level(and unlock the next quest), the boss battles can be challenging, and good fun.  Along with these are "Oaths of Honor", which are small challenges to make the run more difficult(Example, complete the quest under a set time, or use no potions).  You can jump into battle with one of the six characters in the game.  Do you want to charge in swords-a-blazing?  Snipe your foes with a longbow?  Crush everyone with a Cestus?  The choice is yours.Anyway, I hope this review has helped you decide on this game(And hopefully, I got it accurate xD).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Beautiful game. Amazing storyline. Creative monsters. Prelude to my second favorite game made by Nexon.This game has the most beautiful artwork and concepts of armor I have ever seen. Each character is crafted as their own. While the facial features might be the same for all characters, it really doesn't matter when you can personalize any way you want from skin tone to make-up to even under armor. The characters move so in tune with their weapons nothing seems unnatural.The storyline is fantastic, especially because this is all a prelude to Nexon's Mabinogi. This game is much more serious than Mabinogi and it certainly gives you a break from the care-free enviroment of it, which is sometimes nice. The storyline I can keep track of pretty well with easy to remember names and (regretably) a very small map with 2 towns, one you are in 90% of the time. The monsters are your usual monsters, but with a little twist and have such amazing graphics and design to them. Gnolls are transformed and given clever names, ranks, titles and even abilities and stray from your usual dog-man creature. Nexon really nailed it on this one when it comes to 3D monster art.As I said before, this game leads up to Nexon's Mabinogi (which is another great game by them). This clears up some of the plot to Mabinogi and this is all around a good plot on it's own.This game is absolutely perfect for a gamer who loves running dungeons with an amazing looking character. If you aren't downloading this now, you should.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												I played this game before it was even on steam. This game takes aspects from two of my favorite genres. It has skills and classes from a typical MMORPG, but then in the combat it takes on aspects of a live-action MOBA (non-rts) style. I would highly recommend this to both casual and hardcore gamers due to its high  potential and tactics when fighting harder enemies. The beginning of the games is slow though, enemies are easy, no one has any troubles, and typically it feels like a grind-fest. However once you get further in the game and get a more in depth touch, you really get engaged in the fast paced, high action, and VERY difficult boss fights.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
												I have been waiting for the right time to leave my review and because of RECENT CONTROVERSIES, today is the day I do it.The good: CombatEasily the best out of every MMORPG, nothing comes close. Graphics.Pretty good graphics considering its age. At one point, the lighting/reflections in this game was the best I've seen. In fact, it rivalled AAA titles back in ~2010 when DX11 was uncommon. Music.Music is great, some of the best instrumentals I've heard. When I quit this game, I'll be listening to the OST into the far future for sure. Reasonably bugfree.Bug fixes may a take a while, but they eventually arrive.The bad: FPS and Client/Server instability.It is impossible to have a solid 60 FPS and the game crashes for no reason. Optimization is urgently needed but that appears to be low priority. The crashes are few and far between, but it is worth mentioning. The anticheat software is unreliable as proven by the abundancy of bots and for some reason it occassionally uses all of your CPU. Nexon NA.Official forums are heavily moderated. Seemingly normal posts get deleted because of "FUD" (fear, uncertainty and doubt). The definition of this appears to depend on the weather. I heard the anticheat software can trigger false positives, which means players can get permanently banned for no reason. Somewhat pay2win/pay2progress.You can obtain almost everything for free if you grind enough, but real money helps a lot. The game has high upkeep if you want some of the nicer things such as hair and extra inventory space.So, after about 10000 hours I'll probably play in a different region, quit Vindictus or quit MMORPGs entirely. At the end of the day, the game is good if you want to bash some monsters into the ground. But is the combat good enough to make people stay? Give it a shot, I somehow played this game for 10000 hours while hating it the entire time.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game is actually one of the Better MMORPGs I have played in all my years of PC gaming. From the astonishing graphics, to the fairly good optimization, to the story itself, it is a great game. Oh, and those animations? Amazing. Plus, at level 12, the Evie class gains the ability to use a scythe, which scythe-using classes are always a plus in games for me. There is, however, fairly bad population lag if you have and old CPU, but that's really nothing if you play on a less populated channel. I'd give this game a solid 9/10 rating, and highly recommemd it to anyone interested in True-Action, Dungeon-Crawler MMORPGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												It's basically a hack and slash in the source engine. Sounds fun, but fails in a lot of areas.+Nice Graphics+Decent Combat Controls+Easy to learn combos-No real LODs for models. Instead everyone on the server looks like they're wear monk robes while they load for some reason.-Terrible, semi-unskippable text dialogue everywhere.-Little to no weapon variety. Your character usually has 1-2 weapon types they can ever use. Every weapon of that type is only an upgrade to the last, with no specialized versions.-Character customization is insanely overpriced. $30 for digital clothes alone. -You rent in game items for real money when you can't afford the permanent versions. Even when renting the prices are rarely under $7 for a week.-Ads for you to purchase in-game items everywhere.-Absolutely no exploration at all. You never really get to go anywhere. Just tiny town with 4 buildings, to a boat, to a series of rooms where you hit things until they die.-Assets are overused for enemies and levels, making the whole thing feel very lazily made.The only reason I play this is because I can't get my friends to play anything else yet.

												Let me tell you a story of how it all went down... I was able to jump, from that point on I gave the game a 20/10 but then out of no where my character needed a wheel chair, this mofo couldn't jump no more, he had no hops, I was upset. Then out in the distance I saw Shrek he came to me and whispered in my ear " I know why you can't jump anymore " with an evil lookin' grin. My whole body shivered. I was afraid but happy at the same time... to think that Shrek did this to me, out of everyone, I should be glad. Right? Yeah. Oh yeah, back to the game. 												I love the game-Its simple to play, hard to master-Each class has special abilities that allow for diverse play styles -Money transactions are purely cosmetic as most any gear or item is craftable or lootable (or is given to you in events)-Bosses are epic and some require real skill to beat (at least with certain characters)-Game has difficulty so it sort of encourages coop play-So far the community seems great-Encountered some texture glitches and lag but nothing worth whining about really-A lot of balance in items and moves that make sure you aren't a god (at least until high levels)-Skills are focused on micromanaging every aspect of your character (this can be overwhelming at times)All in all I recommend the game and you should play it

content:
Posted: April 22, 2013
												This MMORPG is yet another great example of the free-to-play niche. The game is stunning, full of vibrant charm inspired by Korean-Japanese culture and European middle ages. What you have here is a massive package of free content. The game let's you pick three different fully fleshed out playstyles from the hard hitting sophisticated art of magic and alchemy to the brutally accurate archer.  There are tons of missions to partake in, a load of different weapons and armors with impressivly great design to choose from as well. A fully realized upgrade and leveling system is also present. The combat is real time and stylishly brutal! The music is also great! If you like RPGs then this game is more than standard fare. Try it out if you're interested, it's extremely fun and free! You've got nothing to lose!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												The story was mildly intriguing, but it was disappointing that I did not get to fight side-by-side with any of the important NPCs. Instead, the reality of this world is left to be told via text and unanimated 2D pictures of the NPCs. And the dialogue is not good enough to jump off the screen on its own.The combat mechanics are tolerable, but the difficulty was laughably easy. However, it was not the lack of difficulty that annoyed me most about the dungeons but the bland, monotonous layouts of the environments -- and every dungeon is a single, closed path. There is no heart nor soul to the world, and it all feels impersonal and empty.But, I did have a little fun regardless of all the boringness. I've just no interest in continuing to play it further.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I've played Vindictus since the start of OBT. I've played the game for many hours throughout these few years, and I must say that this game is by far the most addictive game I've ever come across with. With that said, here are my pros and cons.Pros:Hack and Slash - This game is unique in game-play with it's hack and slash mechanics. I have played many hack and slash games, and I can say none of them compete well with Vindictus. It's battle system has kept me playing for years. It's combos gave me a rush of dopamine from the get-go. I got hooked, and it felt good. Character Diversity - Each character has it's unique play-style. Currently, you can play as 8 characters. Lann, Fiona, Evie, Karok, Kai, Vella, Hurk, Lynn, and soon Arisha. Each character is unique in battle. Even while Vella and Lann share the same weapon (Twin Swords), they feel very much different from one another. I've tried each character, and can see similarities among them, but they stand out on their own.The Abundance of Channels - Each Server has a total of 200 channels. Whether you want to interact, or play alone, channels provide a spot for everyone. The Story - The story is beautiful. I will not explain it, I don't like giving story spoilers. I will say, this game would be an amazing anime.Cons:RNG - Of course, this will be my first con to list. The RNG (Random Number Generator) of this game is very broken. You want to gear up, and enhance as best as you can? Gear enhancement can be very, very risky. After +6, you will risk the enhancement to 0, and after +8, you risk breaking.Some people have a lot of luck, and could possibly go from +0 to +15 in one go, but that's extremely rare.A lot of players resort to buying NX to buy Enhancement Runes to protect their arsenal.Over all, the RNG seems really unfair to everyone.Drop Rate - This goes along with the RNG. The drop rate sucks in this game, even with VIP, or VVIP services (which range from 10$ to 20$ a month) most of the drops end up being garbage.Server Stability - (Peer to Peer) - More times than not, I stay away from 24-man raids, and leave boats where the host only has 1 bar. Peer to Peer works great in Korea, but face it... North America is much more vast than South Korea.Bots - This game is infested with bots. These bots also inflate the economy, making things harder to earn.Depot Shop/Avatar Shop Pricing - The prices tend to be high up there. Though, you do not have to buy anything from these shops, people prefer to buy to look good, or gear up better. The game can have it's ugly pay2win moments.Recycled Dungeons - Perilous Ruins, Ruins of Sanctity, and Hilder Forest are the same maps. After a while, everything looks familiar, and dull. Prairie Entrance and Fomorian Base are purposely the same location. (Fobellow Prairie). That includes Ainle, and The Catacombs. (Night time, and Day time)Community - The community of this game can either be amazingly awesome, or terribly annoying.It ranges from down to earth people who actually play this game, to sorry people who try to tell you how to play the game, and act like they are a better person than you based on their numbers. Though, this is in every game, it's something one must learn to endure in MMORPGs.My Rating:Gameplay: 8/10Story: 8/10Server Stability: 5/10Community: 4/10Dungeons: 6/10Premium Shops: 6/10Overall Rating: 6/10.NOTE: Despite of my review and rating, I recommend this game. You should try it for yourself before you make any conclusions.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												A pretty solid hack-and-slash MMO. It plays out a bit like a cross between Diablo and a slightly toned-down Monster Hunter. Decent number of classes/characters, combat's pretty satisfying, and it definitely has one of the fairest Free-to-Play systems I've seen outside of Valve titles. Unfortunately, the upgrade trees are a little lackluster (you'll have unlocked every skill after just a few hours if you try to, leaving only fairly minor statistical improvements), the game does have a bit of a lag problem when there's a group of enemies on screen, and while the boss fights are definitely a highlight, the cannon fodder enemies and environments don't have as much diversity as I would have liked (you'll be wandering through the same areas and slaying a lot of the same basic creatures in between boss encounters). Overall, though, it's one of the better F2P games on Steam and definitely worth a look for fans of the genre.

												A pretty solid hack-and-slash MMO. It plays out a bit like a cross between Diablo and a slightly toned-down Monster Hunter. Decent number of classes/characters, combat's pretty satisfying, and it definitely has one of the fairest Free-to-Play systems I've seen outside of Valve titles. Unfortunately, the upgrade trees are a little lackluster (you'll have unlocked every skill after just a few hours if you try to, leaving only fairly minor statistical improvements), the game does have a bit of a lag problem when there's a group of enemies on screen, and while the boss fights are definitely a highlight, the cannon fodder enemies and environments don't have as much diversity as I would have liked (you'll be wandering through the same areas and slaying a lot of the same basic creatures in between boss encounters). Overall, though, it's one of the better F2P games on Steam and definitely worth a look for fans of the genre.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I absolutely love the action combat of this game because it requires precision and strategic approach to most of the Hero Mode bosses/raids but allows you to just spam click your way through everything else for the fun Hack 'n Slash aspecs of this genre.  Dodging attacks is pretty easy for most classes but some are unlucky in not having any invincibility frames in their dodge when wielding certain weapons but for the most part all mobs/bosses give plenty of tell-tale signs of which kind of attack is coming.     There are many different kinds of weapons that have very different play styles and most of the gender locked classes can wield two types, which are unchangable during missions but can be freely swapped everywhere else.  Many different types of enchantable gear to upgrade your characters with [jewelry, standard armor pieces, costume parts with stat boost, etc] but &^$%, Forge Upgrading your armor/weapons past +6 is aggravating, and forget about +10 and higher unless you're filthy rich.     To be honest though, as much as I love this game, I find it very rage inducing due to these few reasons:  Dodging and attacking, Equipment Random Number Generator and Enchanting.  The dodging and attacking around bosses can be really fun but sometimes a few mistakes will cost you an expensive self rez item, especially if you don't want to wait 24 hours to refight the special/raid boss for a chance of a high valued drop.  Other times you'll find that team mates will kite a bosses incoming attack haphazardly which makes the whole 'unlucky positioning' a regular thing unless you just try to dodge everything, whether aimed at you or not, causing the overall fight to take longer.  The random number generator for upgrading/finding quality gear is standardly unfair unless you spend real-life money to prevent your gear from being destroyed on failed attempts.  The same can be said about finding and using the Enchantment Scrolls which makes having optimally Enchanted-Enhanced Weapons, Armor and Jewelry an annoyingly difficult and arduous task to complete.  Overall though its a game I've enjoyed plenty for extended periods of time and after long breaks as well.  I highly recommend giving it a few plays.

content:
Posted: January 6
												I always come crawling back to this game... I am an avid Vindictus player. I play on and off and have started since the beta with only Lann, Evie, and Fiona. The game has undergone a lot of changes but the core is the same. Of course there are some pay 2 win elements but that doesn't hurt the game in my opinion. The visuals, music, and gameplay are all still top notch for such an old game and for anyone looking to play an mmorpg with friends you should definitely try this one out! (Also note the majority of the population is at end game)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												(Steam Review)Nearing 200hrs of on and off gametime. This is your standard hack n slash BUT, the combat is by far the greatest any game may have. Every frame, movement, hitbox, phases are incredibly smooth and is what keeps this game alive (aside from the cosmetics which actually keeps it alive). If you're going to be an on and off again player I highly recommend putting a couple of points into Meditation. Although the time reduction may seem minimal it will definitely stack up over time. I haven't done the exact math on this but, there have been times where I've logged in and seen a nice chunk of AP waiting to be used. Pros: Free to play, progress at a steady pace, NOT A CONSTANT MOB GRIND (like Maplestory), Incredible combat mechanics, characters feel unique and have their own playstyles. Characters can be almost completely customized (free) down to their eyes, body sizes, etc... The solo combat outweighs the Cons but only by a slim margin. It doesn't matter what class you pick, the best class changes often with little changes put out. The new updates have made it so the game runs perfectly smooth on my PC where in the pass it has not.Cons of the game: Dungeons will feel very repetitive (I'm only lvl67 atm, doing Season 1 battle quests). The only fun moments are when I finally get to the boss or am in a raid. Player base is extremely low, you can indeed pay to win but I don't think it's neccessary, LACK of permanent cosmetic events, butchered Raids (I hardly see anyone doing the 20+man raids nowadays with their new system, I used to be able to que up and the notifier would actually pop up and tell me to join). LOCKED gender classes so everyone of ie: Kai class will be males.If Nexon put out more events for lower level players/new players the game would be able to get more traffic. The playerbase needs to increase to help the game out more than anything at the moment.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												The game uses a "hub" system. Combat is instanced in small (and incredibly repetitive) areas. Content is recycled for about 20 levels all the way up to level cap, meaning for every twenty levels of play you're killing the same stuff, but recolored, in the same areas, either forward, or backward. Classes are varied, but they are also gender-locked. Some classes have a lot of similarity, but they simply created a female version because thongs sell better than boxers (no joke, females are basically barbie dolls to dress up). Content is plentiful, but experiencing and unlocking this content is a nightmare. You are expected to run the same dungeons over and over, and when you're not doing that, you're reading (or skipping) long, tedious storylines that you are only able to skip one dialogue sentence at a time (how long can your index finger or thumb mash on those buttons before they're just sore?).This means that even when they have Bonus EXP events, you will actually out-level the content that you're in. You are REQUIRED to play a lot of missions twice or more in order to fully "complete" the requirements to unlock the next mission. There are at least THREE LAYERS of restrictions on content, either "Completion" points, "storyline" completion or "character level". These three restrictions can be infuriating to deal with, since the majority of the content in the game (the normal story missions) can literally be completed in a matter of minutes.I am not joking when I say you will spend more time talking (reading text) to NPCs than you will actually doing missions. You will have to talk to one, two, three, four or more NPCs to learn about a particular mission, and then it will only take you about two minutes SOLO to complete said mission. Only exception to this is Raid Bosses. They are the only fun element in Vindictus, but if you play in a full party (there is no level restrictions, you can get hard carried in these raids) then you can normally get away with dancing in a corner doing nothing while your allies whipe the boss in several minutes.Another problem with this game is the business model. They've tried to be as fair as possible, but in the end what they've come up with is a system that heavily rewards paying users by giving them more exp, more loot, better loot, better consumables (potions you can drink while laying on the ground), more teamplay items (revive tokens etc) and just overall a better experience.Being a free player in Vindictus is tedious, tiresome and not necessarily rewarding. To be a free player you need to spend dozens of hours preparing for the next section of the game either by crafting, buying/selling on the market or collecting mats from dungeons. This process is incredibly time-consuming, and does not feel rewarding. Finally acquiring that "next level" set of armor is only the first part of the puzzle. You will craft items in random (and disquesting) colors so if you care even a little bit what you look like then you'll be obligated to proceed to the next part of the process which is customizing the color.If you do not buy things with real money you will literally be spending millions of gold (3.5mil approx for one color) to get the specific colors that you want. If you don't mind wasting time (and gold) you can roll for random colors for signifigantly less, but normally you will get hard clashing colors, desaturated colors, or poop brown. A lot of the time there is one item in the set that simply does NOT roll the same colors as the rest of the outfit, so you will have a clashing color no matter how much time and effort you spend rolling. Best bet is to farm gold to buy dyes directly from players. Unless you're fine with spending $3 to randomly get a color from six possibilities. Yeah, you read that right. $3 to gamble colors. That's Vindictus.The other things you can buy through the real-money store is essentially wigs and underwear. There is a "depot" that contains pets, consumables etc. and if you plan to be a serious Vindictus player then you simply can't get away with NOT buying from the depot.Casual players will want their characters to look decent, so they will likely want a wig and some underwear. $10 a piece. Why? Because breast physics and buttcracks. If you use the default, you'll have an ugly white cotton undershirt and shorts. Basically all the armor sets are designed WITHOUT these inner-armors in mind, so they will stick out like a sore thumb.With all of these things listed above I simply will not recommend this game to anybody, ever. The business model is awful and punishes free players in almost every possible way. The pacing of the game is incredibly inconsistent and painful (literally, my finger & thumb go numb when I play for more than 30 minutes) and the story is your typical Eastern Anime-themed "Oh noes I'm a diety but because I'm a helpless girl I need every strong man to save me from stupid situations" and frankly it drove me nuts. You're a member of a mercenary group and the amount of petty squabbles, incompetent recruits (and generals) and whatnot is just appalling. It's hard to believe that these people even know which end of the sword to carry.Don't bother with Vindictus. When it first came out it was basically the first Western MMO to play like this, but now we have different games that do the same thing in a much more fair and reasonable fashion (Tera, for example). This game will try your patience, hurt your fingers, frustrate you when it should be entertaining you. Unless you're a horny teenage boy or girl that likes looking up skirts, avoid like the plague.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Vindictus is a fun game, but sadly its deteriorated into a pay2win game with horrible customer service. The game has been steadily losing population for the last year and Nexon doesn't feel like fixing the game since that doesn't bring in money. They are more focused on releasing Inner Armor for the females so people can clothe their waifus in bikinis. There is nothing in the game for low levels and grouping with your peers at low levels is basically non existant. What end game they have is a grind fest, and by that I mean it takes weeks to get a certain piece you need to improve your gear, and there is a good chance you will lose that piece of gear in the process. Don't waste your time, stay away from this game.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Although Nexon's "Mabinogi" MMORPG title has more of an original and unique feel to it, Vindictus has its ups and downs. I adore all of the games that Nexon makes, especially that of Mabinogi and Maplestory. I have put a lot of hours into Vindictus and was a beta tester for the game.Throughout the years I have come to the conclusion that this game is for the type of people who want hack n' slash ability and yearn for a-lot of carnage. The online servers have a few bugs but other than that, people who enjoy totally annihilating your opponent and/or having fun with friends, it's a good idea to try this game out. Totes fun.

												pretty rad if you like to play an mmo where most players (if you run into any) have already capped and treat you like garbage because you havent hit lvl 90, ghost town? nope try ghost world....gameplay is ok i do feel full controller would be nice so i dont have to take my hands off, look down away from the boss, find the key, press it, look up and find out im already dead.i dont like how i have to spend tons of cash on extras. (hey nexon how about imply a cheap month to month member system like runescape and make players spend ap on extras)this game has sucked my life away though. i spend most of my free time playing it, which is weird because i have an xbone and fh3 to get back to...it is addicting i'll give it thatbut there are improvements to be made if they want their players back because as it sits the community is dead and the more that quit will cause it to die faster and thats xp,ap,time and irl cash wasted.i suggest making improvements; big ones at that, improve advertising of said improvements, raise lvl cap and remove the need to spend actual money anytime you want something cool, imply a member system (you already have vip but make it so it lasts longer and makes it so you can spend gold or ap on outfits,weapons,etc.)make a larger map instead of the two cities you can walk into and the two other towns you can travel to. people like large scale free roam. bring back your community and maybe this game will be more than halfway decent.freebies are not always enough.i do however reccomend this game if you like grinders.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												I cannot believe how long I have spent playing this game but getting back into it, it's good and it's a different kind of MMO. It's quite honestly the best MMO to get if you want an online version of, for example purproses, Devil May Cry. The classes are genderlocked so that's a shame but then every Korean MMO is. Anyways this game is fun for a bit but the crafting and economy is a pain in the butt to deal with. But the last time I've played this game was back in 2007 so maybe it's changed I'm not so sure. Anyways the game does a good job of making you feel like a total badass towards Endgame and it's fun going on the huge and complicated raid bosses. Overall I'd say it's a solid 8/10

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												The story was mildly intriguing, but it was disappointing that I did not get to fight side-by-side with any of the important NPCs. Instead, the reality of this world is left to be told via text and unanimated 2D pictures of the NPCs. And the dialogue is not good enough to jump off the screen on its own.The combat mechanics are tolerable, but the difficulty was laughably easy. However, it was not the lack of difficulty that annoyed me most about the dungeons but the bland, monotonous layouts of the environments -- and every dungeon is a single, closed path. There is no heart nor soul to the world, and it all feels impersonal and empty.But, I did have a little fun regardless of all the boringness. I've just no interest in continuing to play it further.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												The story and characters are bad bad bad bad bad bad bad. The writing is downright awful and so long-winded that I dreaded every time I finished a story mission because I knew what I would be subjecting myself to when returned to town. No amount of heavy drinking can make me give a single damn about any of these one-dimensional stereotypes and their emotional instabilities.But seriously. Don't read the story. Just click until it's over. The wellness of your soul is a stake.If you came for the gameplay, it's pretty decent. Some of the characters are unique enough to be interesting, but the levels are repetitive and clearing the way to a boss is boringly easy. On top of that, the late game feels sloppy and unbalanced. The easiest way around that is to hand Nexon tons of money. They love money.The final nail in the coffin for me is that the nighmarishly slow server lag over the past few months (Yes. Months.) has rendered this game fairly unplayable. It' too bad that I kind of liked it.Kind of.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Ok, on my preveious Steam account I've played this game for a quite a while and really, I dont exactly not recommend this game, only thing is that there are way better games out there for you to get. This game has big bosses and pretty good graphics for a f2p mmo. Thing is that it's not what you may think it is. If you're looking for a game where you can farm currency and not be totally outmatched by people who pay, this game doesn't exactly fit that bill. You better expect to grind for all raw materials, armor, and weapons. Another thing is that this game isn't a casual game, in order to succeed in this game you better be prepared to do overtime; otherwise the unimmersive story will eventually bore you. This game is not even close to being an RPG, the story is dull and the game didnt focus on anything but combat. The combo based hack and slash combat is fast paced and fluid, but there is only one race and the classes are simply put, "Gun, magic, or melee weapon?" This game does have a lot of things that make it unique and worthwhile, but when you look at the whole picture, this game isn't worth your time. If you want mindless dungeon massacres and random big bosses, then this is the game for you. If you want detailed story and lore you can immerse yourself into. If you want to play wheather you have 20 minutes or 2 hours. If you want to RP with people and have a variety of races and classes that really make you think on how you play. To you I say avoid this game and play a real MMORPG.

												The story and characters are bad bad bad bad bad bad bad. The writing is downright awful and so long-winded that I dreaded every time I finished a story mission because I knew what I would be subjecting myself to when returned to town. No amount of heavy drinking can make me give a single damn about any of these one-dimensional stereotypes and their emotional instabilities.But seriously. Don't read the story. Just click until it's over. The wellness of your soul is a stake.If you came for the gameplay, it's pretty decent. Some of the characters are unique enough to be interesting, but the levels are repetitive and clearing the way to a boss is boringly easy. On top of that, the late game feels sloppy and unbalanced. The easiest way around that is to hand Nexon tons of money. They love money.The final nail in the coffin for me is that the nighmarishly slow server lag over the past few months (Yes. Months.) has rendered this game fairly unplayable. It' too bad that I kind of liked it.Kind of.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												The game uses a "hub" system. Combat is instanced in small (and incredibly repetitive) areas. Content is recycled for about 20 levels all the way up to level cap, meaning for every twenty levels of play you're killing the same stuff, but recolored, in the same areas, either forward, or backward. Classes are varied, but they are also gender-locked. Some classes have a lot of similarity, but they simply created a female version because thongs sell better than boxers (no joke, females are basically barbie dolls to dress up). Content is plentiful, but experiencing and unlocking this content is a nightmare. You are expected to run the same dungeons over and over, and when you're not doing that, you're reading (or skipping) long, tedious storylines that you are only able to skip one dialogue sentence at a time (how long can your index finger or thumb mash on those buttons before they're just sore?).This means that even when they have Bonus EXP events, you will actually out-level the content that you're in. You are REQUIRED to play a lot of missions twice or more in order to fully "complete" the requirements to unlock the next mission. There are at least THREE LAYERS of restrictions on content, either "Completion" points, "storyline" completion or "character level". These three restrictions can be infuriating to deal with, since the majority of the content in the game (the normal story missions) can literally be completed in a matter of minutes.I am not joking when I say you will spend more time talking (reading text) to NPCs than you will actually doing missions. You will have to talk to one, two, three, four or more NPCs to learn about a particular mission, and then it will only take you about two minutes SOLO to complete said mission. Only exception to this is Raid Bosses. They are the only fun element in Vindictus, but if you play in a full party (there is no level restrictions, you can get hard carried in these raids) then you can normally get away with dancing in a corner doing nothing while your allies whipe the boss in several minutes.Another problem with this game is the business model. They've tried to be as fair as possible, but in the end what they've come up with is a system that heavily rewards paying users by giving them more exp, more loot, better loot, better consumables (potions you can drink while laying on the ground), more teamplay items (revive tokens etc) and just overall a better experience.Being a free player in Vindictus is tedious, tiresome and not necessarily rewarding. To be a free player you need to spend dozens of hours preparing for the next section of the game either by crafting, buying/selling on the market or collecting mats from dungeons. This process is incredibly time-consuming, and does not feel rewarding. Finally acquiring that "next level" set of armor is only the first part of the puzzle. You will craft items in random (and disquesting) colors so if you care even a little bit what you look like then you'll be obligated to proceed to the next part of the process which is customizing the color.If you do not buy things with real money you will literally be spending millions of gold (3.5mil approx for one color) to get the specific colors that you want. If you don't mind wasting time (and gold) you can roll for random colors for signifigantly less, but normally you will get hard clashing colors, desaturated colors, or poop brown. A lot of the time there is one item in the set that simply does NOT roll the same colors as the rest of the outfit, so you will have a clashing color no matter how much time and effort you spend rolling. Best bet is to farm gold to buy dyes directly from players. Unless you're fine with spending $3 to randomly get a color from six possibilities. Yeah, you read that right. $3 to gamble colors. That's Vindictus.The other things you can buy through the real-money store is essentially wigs and underwear. There is a "depot" that contains pets, consumables etc. and if you plan to be a serious Vindictus player then you simply can't get away with NOT buying from the depot.Casual players will want their characters to look decent, so they will likely want a wig and some underwear. $10 a piece. Why? Because breast physics and buttcracks. If you use the default, you'll have an ugly white cotton undershirt and shorts. Basically all the armor sets are designed WITHOUT these inner-armors in mind, so they will stick out like a sore thumb.With all of these things listed above I simply will not recommend this game to anybody, ever. The business model is awful and punishes free players in almost every possible way. The pacing of the game is incredibly inconsistent and painful (literally, my finger & thumb go numb when I play for more than 30 minutes) and the story is your typical Eastern Anime-themed "Oh noes I'm a diety but because I'm a helpless girl I need every strong man to save me from stupid situations" and frankly it drove me nuts. You're a member of a mercenary group and the amount of petty squabbles, incompetent recruits (and generals) and whatnot is just appalling. It's hard to believe that these people even know which end of the sword to carry.Don't bother with Vindictus. When it first came out it was basically the first Western MMO to play like this, but now we have different games that do the same thing in a much more fair and reasonable fashion (Tera, for example). This game will try your patience, hurt your fingers, frustrate you when it should be entertaining you. Unless you're a horny teenage boy or girl that likes looking up skirts, avoid like the plague.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Vindictus is an action beat em up developed by devcat and published by Nexon. The game launched around five or so years back and has been filling with content since.   The Game had small peaks in popularity but it honestly deserves much better than others let it on to be.  This game is however not without faults but if you can live without them you can probably see yourself right at home with this game. GraphicalThe graphics of Vindictus are pretty nice and have aged well despite it being 2016, game is limited to directX 9.0 and textures are pretty clean. Character models are very impressive and there are a wide variety of monster models and armor sets. For a free to play game this does not disapoint.  Sound	The sound effects are pretty good but the lack of ability to turn off fanfares can be kind of annoying, the options menu does not seem to allow me to turn off or adjust the volume of the game. I had to resort to windows audio mixer but whatever.   General Gameplay	Gameplay for vindictus is very thrilling, even the lower levels you'll find yourself having loads of fun completely destroying enemies later on the challenge really picks up in the mid game.  45+ is when I started having to play more conservatively.  They give you three bags I personally struggled to maintain item space with three and ended up buying bag space which costed real money. It really all depends how much you value holding onto your items.  Progression	Progression in the game has really changed from launch you wont be repeating quests anytime soon as the game will give you a smooth ride to 60+.   As you level up and complete battles you will gain AP this works similar to mabinogi if you have played the game.  You will spend AP to rank skills up starting from Rank F going to Rank 1.  Some skills only go upto certain ranks.    Gear progession is something I can only speak from my way upto level 60, you are greeted with a ton of variety I believe this is due to the games original cap. There is a huge lacking in items to buy off the market board making your only option as to grind the bosses for the materials which really does boil down to RNG.  It will probably take you a few hours to get the set you want. Players are more than willing to run too, I play on the east server and have had tons of players jump in on the fun slaughtering the boss over and over.   This has made it very bareable for me. Combat When you begin the game you will be greeted to a character selection screen, each character has thier own traits and abilites. Characters range from fast attackers, to bursty or half magic/half melee mages.   the variety has something for everyone even grapplers will feel at home. There is a very hack and slash feeling to the game.  Combos are generated by left and right mouse clicks.  Left being your general melee and right being your smash attack. you will perform combos based on number of left clicks combined with right click.  Some combos have extra conditions.You are given secondary weapon choices ranging from hooks to spears to bombs all used with the F key, you can only have one with you and each has its own function. Later into the game around level 40 you'll be given the ability to go either "Paladin" or "Dark knight"  Each with thier own perks but both very benefiting on all characters so no choice is wrong.  Thoughts on the cash shop	The Cash shop is pretty pricey but not completely overpowering as I thought it would be, you gain some stats from cosmetics but they are only a very tiny fraction of stats that only shadows your armor.  I feel like storage space prices are a bit ridiculous(13-USD) as I feel the perm bags are the correct choice over rental bags. This can be daunting and make you feel like you are limited to playing one character if you don't make a whole lot of income to shell out.(Again this is based on perspective some people are good at managing their inventory space.)  There are gatcha and plenty of cosmetics to choose from if you really like the look.  I feel like the armor in the game looks amazing so it really does not matter if you choose to take cosmetic or not.   Again nothing overpowering but really too expensive. Story The story is very good for an free to play title, the characters are actually memorable and quirky I can't beleive that is actaully fun to read as you progress.  The plot is nothing too special however and you'll find that aspect to be pretty dull and just plain silly as you level further. The neat characters do seem to damper outside of the starting village.  I didn't have the same level of awe with the characters in the castle city as I did in the small mercenary camp.  Despite this, its still mildy interesting and actually gives the gameplay meaning.  It's executed very well.  Is vindictus worth playing?	I would say its worth playing, it has hours of content. Bosses are fun and engaging and all stay unuiqe into the endgame. Character progression is good and there are tons of playstyles. Story has great characters and the game can be enjoyed solo or with a group of friends. The game really has come a long way from launch. It has no fatigue system or anything that punishes people for wanting to actually play the game.  It's hack and slash with a great curve of difficulty.   Should you play this?  Yes, yes, absolutely yes...  Free to play games are generally not this good.
